Posted: July 28, 2013
												I know this almost goes without saying, but any gamer alive should play the Half-Life games. Even compared with the modern flashy big-budget single-player shooter extravaganzas of today (I'm looking at you, Far Cry and Bioshock), which are rightly heralded as amazing games, Half-Life makes your jaw drop at how amazing of an experience it is to fight throuth the crumbling Black Mesa facility battling humans and headcrabs alike. This game really makes you realize how much Jason Brody, Booker Dewitt, and every other major  fps protagonist since owe the man with the crowbar, Gordon Freeman. If you are a sane human being who can play a video game, there is no excuse for you to not play Half-Life. None!

number of helpful: 443 of 586 people (76%) found this review helpful54 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												Half-Life: Source is the 2004 port of Valve's award winning game to the Source Engine. With just that knowledge, it would sound like Half-Life: Source was a gift from above, but it's anything BUT that. Half-Life: Source was critically panned, which makes you wonder HOW it has a "Very Positive" on Steam Reviews. Half-Life: Source is one of those games Valve chooses to forget, with the likes of the first Left 4 Dead and Ricochet. But, before we get into a review, lets go over the history of Half-Life: Source.The History:In 1999, Valve started development of Half-Life 2, the award winning squeal to Half-Life, originally running on the GoldSource engine. Around 2001/2002, the Source Engine was created, and it surpassed what the GoldSource engine could do, so, Valve planned to port Half-Life to the Source Engine to have it replace the GoldSource counter parts. In 2003, Axel Gambe got a hold of the full Half-Life 2 Source Code, raw map data, and a build of Half-Life 2, who later gave it to some friends, who leaked it. In those leak files, there was the Half-Life Source port, along with files to a Source port of TFC, DMC, and CS 1.6 (which was remotely playable, but at this time, this port was starting to become the game we know today as CS:S.) The port of Half-Life: Source was quite buggy and unfinished, which is to be expected for it being a leak of a beta. So, 2004 comes around, and then Half-Life 2 is coming around the corner, as a bundle with Half-Life 2, you could get Counter-Strike: Source (by this time is the game we all know and probably love) and Half-Life: Source. Half-Life: Source saw little change from the 2003 leak of Half-Life 2, minus some minor bug fixes and having the Half-Life 1 HUD. At this point, be expected Half-Life: Source to be just like Counter-Strike: Source, a re-imagining of the game, in HD (for 2004 standards), but what they got was a direct Half-Life port that didn't seam quite finished. This is why if you ask anyone why they don't like Half-Life: Source for the most part (especially pre-2013) you get told it's graphics were just the Half-Life graphics. But as stated before, Half-Life: Source was meant to replace Half-Life as a whole, but due to how poorly received it was, Half-Life Original saw another day. In 2006, Valve ported the Deathmatch counter part of Half-Life into the Source Engine, and if you thought Half-Life: Source was a bad port, you should of saw this game. All player ragdolls had broken physics, some weapons were broken (the Shotgun's double barrel sound is just the single barrel sound), and the gameplay was more like Half-Life 2 Deathmatch with minor HLDM gameplay stuff slapped in (the game even lacks the backpack pickups that were in Half-Life Deathmatch), the only reason I can see for this port, was just to give EP1 a pack-in game. Around 2007, Half-Life: Source and Deathmatch: Source were ported to Source Base 2007, but due to the amount of bugs now included with the game, Valve didn't release this patch to the public, it wasn't until 2012 that the public knew of this update's existence, since in 2012, the whole 2008/2007 source code to Source Base 2007 was leaked into the public, it also confirmed that the Team Fortress Classic port was in further development than what everyone thought. But due to the amount of hate towards Half-Life: Source and Deathmatch: Source would mean we would probably never seen of these ports.So, that runs down a good chunk of the history of Half-Life: Source besides one of the more major things, the 2013 update. Valve in an effort to ditch the GCF system and upgrade everything to VPK and have a better downloading system and a better game asset pack to engine communication, they created Steampipe, but since Valve decided it would be best to port all games to Source Base 2013, they decided to do that, and try to provide updates to all Valve games. In the same year, Valve canned the project, leaving a ton of games in a broken state, Half-Life: Source being one of them.So, this leads us into the review.The ReviewHalf-Life: Source was a mediocre port to the Source Engine, where it would be mixed who liked the game and disliked the game, since Half-Life: Source had that audience. Half-Life: Source is now a BAD port to the Source Engine, since those 2013 updates broke more than what it fixed. Not only did Valve cancel the updates to these games, they released the beta depots into the release depot to remove traces of GCFs. So, those games that had a good release depot, now have a beta released into them, and a lot of these betas were far from done. We now have broken Save/Restore errors in various NPCs, 2 out of the 3 tentacles in Blast Pit can harm the player or AI, one of the maps in Residue Processing will blind the player if your flashlight is turned on, skill configurations are broken (so now the AI is harder), Gonarch spit is now black squares, one of the maps in Surface Tension has a broken skybox, you can jump over a lot of things making it so you can skip half of "We got Hostiles" and skip various other parts in other chapters, all of the Chrome shaders are complete♥♥♥♥♥(they were never good, but this is just worse), and even more. It's sad when a 2003 leak is better and more playable than a 2013 update. Plus, if you load the HD Pack you get a GameBanana skin pack, since Valve was too lazy to port the assets their selves of even double check to be everything matched in the first place. But the icing on the cake is that, well, at first install, you can't even PLAY Half-Life: Source since Valve provided corrupted or outdated DLLs to Steam VR, so every time you reinstall Half-Life: Source you have to verify the cache of Half-Life 2 or Steam VR. Not only that, the person who was working on these updates, Alfred, shrugged off a few errors as design points.Half-Life: Source had potential to be a great port, to even be on par with the Original Half-Life (definitely should NEVER replace the Original), but its potential was lost with a company who couldn't care enough about the game, which is why it was left for about 6 years without an update.I recommend to play Half-Life: Source and Deathmatch: Source so you can see what happens when a company just flat out doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥Even though I didn't review the pre-2013 build, I'm still going to give it a ratingThe Half-Life: Source that existed before 2013, I give that a 6 out of 10I give the current Half-Life: Source a 4 out of 10, avoid at all costs.Actually, I recommend you report both Half-Life: Source and Deathmatch: Source, as it very unplayable and is using stolen assets. You shouldn't let Valve sell this to people, especially when people think this is the better version of Half-Life

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Would I recommend Half-Life? Hell yes. Would I recommend Half-Life: Source? Er, maybe. The original Half-Life was, and still is, an absolutely fantastic game. The story and how it’s conveyed to the player works extremely well, and the controls, gameplay mechanics, visuals, and sound are all phenomenal. Very few bugs, and certainly none game-breakingly noteworthy.However, this is where Half-Life: Source fails. This game’s major problem is its glitches and bugs. Some minor, some absolutely game-breaking. On one hand, you have scientist’s AI screwed up, running into open fire, constantly shooting off their response lines. On the other hand, you have some parts of the game where the textures and models go ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, essentially simulating your graphics card melting.Even with the bugs, the game does try to make it up with some enhancements thanks to the Source engine. The water effects are slightly better (although in my experiences it’s just extraordinarily shiny and reflective), and the lighting effects are significantly improved, although inconsistent when walking into an area that needs to load. However, the HL2 bullet hole decals make it possible to create magnificent works of art with your crowbar on walls. Thankfully, the gameplay, controls, and overall look and appeal of the game is still there, unaltered. There’s no denying that the game is awesome. Half-Life in general is awesome. I just love how people on the GoldSrc version of Half-Life were complaining about the game having extremely old and outdated graphics, saying HL:Source is better in this field. Well, it’s not. A majority of textures and models are completely identical. Aside from the water and bullet decals, the games are visually the same, which is something I’m completely fine with. The regular version of Half-Life actually comes with the HD texture pack, something this port lacks. It essentially gives the game updated models to characters and weapons, and slightly enhanced textures in some areas. It’s nice, but not essential, which is fine.Overall, yeah, go ahead and get it. If this is ever on sale for cheaper than the regular Half-Life, and you own neither, by all means, go ahead and get it. You (hopefully) won’t regret it.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												I'm not some trolling idiot, I actually love HL1... so please, at least read what I have to say before downvoting, don't act like that just instantly means I hate HL1.Yes, Half Life 1 is one of the best games you'll ever play.  Assuming, of course, that it was designed for its engine.  Meet Half-Life Source, a game that was made on GoldSrc then converted to show off the new engine they had made.HL simply wasn't designed for Source, and no effort was put into properly re-writing the game for the new engine.  The AI is bugged to eternally walk into any wall, I've yet to see a working hitbox, and HL1's graphics are better than this remake.  It's actually unplayable due to the scripted events being broken.  Sorry, that door isn't opening.So you may ask about the low playtime.  Well, when I realized I wouldn't be entering the test chamber, I tried skipping forward a few levels with the map command.  Guess what?  BUGS!  LOTS OF EM!  Nearly anything involving AI interaction would NEVER happen, half the time your enemies can't even hurt you (and vice versa), and a few levelskips forward, I even fell out of the world once when I got hit by a box.Overall, I'm scoring HL Source with a 3/10.  A complete waste of money you're seeing here, it's got to be some sort of joke on Valve's part.  It only scores anything because under the technical crapshow is the 1998 classic that, Xen aside, is nearly perfect.If you want to play the REAL Half-Life bug-free on the GoldSrc engine, click here.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												First, let's get the formalities out of the way. Half-Life is Half-Life. It's unimaginably fantastic. Half-Life Source is different though. It's essentially the same game, just on a more updated engine. And while that might sound like a good thing, Half-Life 1 wasn't designed for the Source engine. It doesn't fit. The updated textures look strange and out of place, it's buggy as all hell, and the AI is changed. That last one's big. Considering there's no cutscenes in Half-Life, any important scenes are done as scripted events. And with the AI different, they just don't act the way they're intended, making you miss important story points. I've also noticed that they move around a lot, so you'll get swarmed real quick, which makes the game go from challenging to unfair. It also doesn't help that weapon switching is unnecessarily slow in this one compared to the original, giving a horde of enemies barrel-assing around the corner ample time to punch holes in you. Also, with the new Source engine, any music that's playing is cut off when you move to the next map, and since there's music cues right before a map change, you'll hear the first five seconds of the song before it just stops playing. Seriously, if you want it, make sure you play the original first. I may have under twenty hours on the Source version, but I have over 130 hours on the GoldSrc version. And that's the campaign alone. Don't be stupid. Get the original.

												I was thinking if I should do a new review for this game or just not even cover it, but I decided to review so here goes.http://steamcommunity.com/id/snortcannon/recommended/70/ My original review of Half Life.Half Life Source is the remastered (if you can call it that) version of the original Half Life. With less game breaking bugs and better textures.At first when I started playing I didn't notice many different things as the game still looks a lot like the original Half Life. Apart from some different textures like the better models and water physics the game looks pretty much identical.My biggest problem with the original version of Half Life was that the game was incredibly buggy. I encountered many game breaking bugs. This wasn't the case with Source. Apart from one chapter where I encountered texture pop ins, I didn't encounter much more.In the end there's nothing more I can say about Half Life Source that I didn't say in my original review. It's a fantastic game and one of my favorite games to date. I highly suggest buying it if you haven't already and playing. Now which version do I recommend playing ? I suggest playing this instead of the original. But I do suggest getting the first one just for Opposing Force and Blue Shift. Final Rating:8/10 - Worth BuyingIf you liked this review please consider giving it a like and if you disliked post in the comments on what you disliked about the review. For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

												There isn't much of a difference between this game and the original Half-Life. If you're deciding which to buy, it honestly doesn't matter. The water is nicer in this game and there are ragdolls and better physics. Other than that, it's essentially the same game. Don't worry about not getting the "pure" experience of HL1 because this is essentially it. Lower resolution water and people who just lay down and die without leaving a ragdoll for you to smack with a crowbar weren't the cornerstones of the Half-Life. Playing HL is an experience, regardless of trivialities such as this.I wouldn't get this by itself personally; if you really wanna pick it up, get it via one of the packs in the Store and/or wait for a sale.One interesting note though, you can load up the content from this game in Garry's Mod. If you have Gmod, this might give you some fun stuff to play around with.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Half-Life is an amazing adventure, sci-fi, and FPS game from Valve.  Your goal is to escape the ruined Black Mesa (the same one that is rivaled with Aperture Science from Portal) while fighting the invading aliens.  Even though first person shooters are generally hated today becayse they are considered rehashes and uncreative, this game is the exact opposite.     You start off in a train ride on your way to some sort of test chamber everyone is talking about.  As you take the ride, you will see a lot of different places that you will visit later, so pay attention.  You eventually make your way to the test chamber when disaster strikes and aliens invade.  It sounds a bit cliche at first, but the game tells the story in such a great way that it works.  You eventually meet a security guard and encounter enemies.  The security guard then helps you, which brings me to my first point.    One amazing thing about Half-Life is that it gives choices.  When you meet the security guard,  you already have your first weapon: a crowbar.  Since a crowbar is a weapon, and there is a person with a gun in front of you, and you need to survive... well, you can see what most people would do.  About 20 minutes into the game, you can already get a gun early, or you can have the security guard help you, until he is apparently can't crawl through a whole that an average scientist can... what a security guard.  This is just one example, and there are a lot of security guards willing to help you.     Anyway, onto the graphics.  They're not as good as other Source games, but don't let that discourage you.  Games are meant to be played, not looked at.  Also, if you want to, you can make the game look like the original Half-Life.     I would reccomend Half-Life to pretty much everbody, as long as you don't get scared easily.  Trust me, you will get a bit scared.  There is a creepy atmosphere, zombies, and A LOT of tension and a feeling you are being watched.  There are no jumpscares are other cheap scares, luckily (I'm looking at you, Slender).  This game gets a 10/10

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Half-Life, the original game from 1998, is possibly my favorite game of all time for reasons of nostalgia, gameplay, story, and the fact that I don't mind the graphics. That being said... This version has taken that amazing game, ported it to the same engine as Half-Life 2, and neglected to fix the  massive  glitches. These include weapons that do not work properly, several graphical problems (If you use the flashlight in a few rooms, the visuals just about break.) Sure, the graphics are 'better' but all that is changed is the blood, lighting and the added ragdoll physics. But these clash with the textures, all of them much lower resolution, making the game look  worse	. I reccomend the original Half-Life, as well as it's expansions and sequels. And if you can't stand the graphics, then I reccomend Black Mesa Source. It's a  much	 better remake of the original Half-Life.

content:
Posted: January 2
												As others have mentioned, the core game is fantastic.   However, the Source port is buggy to the point of distraction - the triggers and interactions that made the original non-Source Half-Life such a revolutionary, tight combo of story and game are broken: * scripted events involving hostiles seem to trigger wrong or not at all ( "I killed twe-RECON! GO GO!" )* wounded NPC's yell over and over and over and over at top volume.* Source physics on the jumping puzzles have taken them from hard to impossible.* Got as far as blast pit, which all sneaking tension is gone and replaced by an indestructable npc shooting the creature over and over again.Half-life (non source) is an awesome game, and it sounds like there may be a better fan-made port in the works.  But stick with the old version if you want the story, and I'm surprised Valve would let anyone curious for the mythos of Half-Life play such a buggy version.  I won't be returning it because hey, I paid $1.99 on a Steam sale, but it seems disinginuous to give a recommendation to this version.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												It's basically the same thing with prettier water, more comfortable flashlight, faster movement speed and ragdolls instead of original death animations. They fixed the Barney's miming of numpad sounds but broke a ton of other things like: specific weapon selection sound, gore, Barney's friendly fire, less blood on walls after shooting, the elevator lights are broken, music stopping after loading, echo in vents and larger areas, the subtle head bobbing, the weapons now have recoil and look more oily, the crowbar makes the same sharp sound when hitting stuff, explosions are less satisfying, transparent water, headcrabs don't move around they just stare at you. But on the other hand: crowbar is stronger, swimming is better, flashlight now casts shadows, the textures look crisper and nicer thanks to shaders, FOV is adjustable and higher in weapons, meaning you can see them better. If you want to play HL1 then play HL1, or try Black Mesa, but HL:S is still HL, so play it anyway, to enjoy the few nuances that make the game even better.

number of helpful: 19 of 25 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												The attention to detail in Valve’s games has never been amiss and I’ve always been impressed by how much they put into this series. The setting for the game is an underground research facility, your character witnesses a catastrophe that plunges the facility into chaos. You have to fend off alien species to escape the facility and try to figure out what is happening. It’s a sci-fi game and that’s what gives it its character. The weapons especially get more interesting as the game develops, as you start to discover more and more alien technology.I used to love watching my dad play this as a kid, but I just never managed to be able to get very far myself until I decided to go back to it now. The Half-Life 1 series is extremely nostalgic to me and its great still being able to play these games despite how old they are. For me, they are great, but I imagine for people that have never played them before, they might just look awful. Despite that, I would hope the overall feel and story of the game would be compelling enough to make those people enjoy it anyway.Half-Life: Source has a few bugs here and there, a few of which I thought were going to be game breaking for me. But there was always a way around it. The glitches and bugs were tedious but given how old the game is it’s forgivable. The source engine reboot of this game changes up the game quite a bit. It was given new map textures, new weapon models, new NPC models and enhances to the sound. The changes are good, they definitely make the game look better. But I enjoy the original just as much, if not more. I’m used to and remember the old one. Which oddly, when I played this game I’m not too sure what happened with it. I downloaded the game, fired it up and played quite a bit in one session. Not noticing that it was all actually the old game assets. I shut it down and gave the game a break and when I booted it back up suddenly the new stuff was being used. Weird!Anyway, there is never a dull moment in this game, there is action and something new always around the corner. It’s essentially a first person shooter, but it manages to break it up in-between and give you enough else to do so that it doesn’t get boring. It’s all around a fun game and I think you should give it a try, even if you haven’t got that Half-Life nostalgia that I do.TL;DR : Old but great, lot of nostalgia for me. It’s a good first person shooter sci-fi game, give it a try.For anyone interested, My Review for Half-Life: Opposing Force:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Stefneh/recommended/50/

												This game has been pretty broken since a recent update to the Source engine. It used to be fine, but after this recent engine change: Barnacles no longer render properly unless you re-enter the room you find them in. The Gonarch (the headcrab boss) now just stands in one spot and spawns a single baby headcrab at a time that just sits under it doing nothing, and his ranged attack makes a black square appear on the floor. map c2a4c has a serious graphical issue where a low-resolution texture tears through everything. See screenshots (1, 2) map c2a5c has a bad skybox which from some angles will render the void as if the map had a leak. See screenshot in several instances, models getting a black texture.Don't get, they probably won't fix this at this point since development on this version of the Source engine has pretty much ended.

content:
Posted: January 8
												Most reviews talk of glitches and bugs but I never encountered a single one. Maybe I was just lucky or maybe the reviewers were lying. Who knows.But anyway. I wanted to check out Half-Life since I got sucked into the Portal universe (and hearing that Aperture Science and Black Mesa were linked somehow) and it was recommended that I get the Source version as opposed to the original. So I did.I actually really enjoyed the story. An experiment at Black Mesa goes wrong and it's up to silent protagonist Gordon Freeman to set it all right again. And despite being a scientist, he's a damn good shot with a gun or he'll really smart you with a crowbar. The gunplay feels good and movement is good, though sometimes jumps can be a little floaty.I never judge a game on graphics but either way, the graphics are good for a game of this agel, and a HD retexture is included. Both sets look good but graphics do not make a game.The gameplay itself is good and the difficulty has good progression, so you start with easier enemies and then as the game progresses, you face tougher enemies. Occasionally the difficulty can spike in places but this is usually doe to miniboss encounters, which is expected.Either way, this was definitely a fun experience and I would highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												For my review of Half-Life, check out my review of the original game. This is just a short insight on my thoughts of the Source version. Half-Life: Source is simply the original Half-Life ported to Valve's newer (at the time) Source engine, it doesn't bring anything new to the table aside from a few new menu options such as selecting a chapter, but it does improve a handful of aspects, mostly minor and technical. The most noteable changes are to the water, the ragdoll physics and the map lighting (in some cases). There are plenty of other minor things that you will notice after playing through once, it's like a new layer of polish, but nothing that would make me recommend buying this version over the original game as unfortunately the Source port has also caused a large number of bugs and errors to arise that were never in the original version. While some of the new features and mechanics in the Source engine are nice, the game hasn't really been updated to take those aspects into account, and thus, more problems popped up. So I have mixed feelings about Half-Life: Source, but I'd say that this version is worth playing through at least once if you are a Half-Life fan, it has a slightly different feel to it but ultimately I'd say to just stick to the original version of the game instead. It may be dated but that's what gives it it's charm.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												First of all this is not a remake (like Black-Mesa), it's a remasterization. Well this is the same old Half Life we all know, except that now it has some improved textures, mainly the metalic ones (incluiding floors), overall lighting, color intensity and all of the character models. The weapons are better looking too as well as your H.E.V. suit (it has nice details on your hands and arms. I recommend it, yes, but only to people that don't own the original or die hard fans like me that would take up any excuse to replay this masterpiece. The thing that bugs me (ignoring the glitches) is that this remasteriztion feels incomplete. Despite they added physics and the death's are more realistic and satisfying (plus the bullet impact splatter and the bullet holes on characters are a nice detail too) now you CAN'T hit them with the crowbar, it just passes through. The only way to "hit" the body is hitting the surface were it is and through the bodu. Only then it'll start moving and it is weird because the hit sound it's still the surface one. If they are re-releasing this too, they should have added something extra, like achievements or cards. I also hate that the impact sounds of the crowbar, even when you are smacking wood, it's METAL-HIT-LIKE SOUND. WHAAT????Finally, I have to say that I played Black Mesa. That is a remake, it has the essence of this game but changed some maps and things (the leechers on the water are gone and the enemies act and react different to the weapons, for example). I liked it and it was a good excuse to travel to Black Mesa again. I still prefer the originall one, but I salute the developers for making an outstanding job at it.

(I have not run into any gamebreaking bugs (I am at the dam in Surface Tensions) I found 3 bugs: the box jumping puzzle the last box slides into the wall, does not affect gameplay. When opening the storm drain in Surface Tensions you can get stuck on top the valve, but I got off by using the grenade launcher.  I saw 2 Marines walking into eachother but that was right after a loading screen and they got out when they saw me.Now onto my review.Half-Life Source is a very well made game. The water and skies look amazing, the lighting is good, and without the High Def Pack (It comes with the Steam version, enable it, it makes the game look very good)  the guns, the models, and textures are decent. Posted: October 18, 2016
												Half-Life is fantastic, but Half-Life: Source is far from a remaster. Whilst rag-dolls and improved water are nice, drawbacks like incorrect lighting in many areas, unnecessary reflections on weapons/models, and various source engine related bugs; it leaves a lot to be desired in a so-called remaster. That's not even taking into account the long loading times that weren't present in the GoldSrc version. Perhaps the only real benefit of Source is proper widescreen, but if you're like me you'll prefer playing Half-Life in 4:3 as originally intended. To summarise just play the GoldSrc version of Half-Life.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Half-LIfe: Source is a, ehem, "remake" of Half-Life 1, which in this case means "we took HL1 recources and transfered them off GoldSrc engine to Source Engine". And yes, it contains single-player campaign of HL1... DeathMatch portion was released serapately later. Though now that you can only purchase bundle of Source with DM, it doesn't matter much. Yes, it comes with HD models from Blue Shift bundledSo, what remake brought? Nothing major. Just small things here and there. First, default things from engine changes - dynamic shadows from flashlight that HL2 Episode 2 brought into engine, for example. There is more of metallic reflective textures, that look ugly in the darkness. The water was changed into HL2 style one... Means more transperency yet the rippling animation was removed. Enemies don't have death animations anymore - they use ragdoll... Which sometimes looks clunky with low-polygon monsters. There are even occasional decoration object that now uses physics, like hooked boxes. And you don't throw boxes away over the hills when you try to move box sideways. At least it all comes along with HD Models pack from Blue Shift.One of the non-graphics changes got to be improved AI, which I also think came. NPCs always react finely, while in original they would often first turn around slowly to face the threat. Security officers that follow you don't get lost as easily, you can even forget about babysitting them. And where in original they had "shoot at some aliens" as high priority, "follow the player" seems to be higher one in this remake... Which means that they will not shoot a thing if they will be busy following strafing player. Guards are better at guard duty, yep. On one of the notes, flying enemy with huge brain in final parts of games is now more aggresive, attempting to get into your face, all the time!Some of the damage values were changed. The biggest example got to be clowbar, it got buffed... Now, just like in HL2, it takes only one hit of this tool to bring down Headcrabs and Barnacles.Some of small bugs in HL1 were fixed, some new small bugs were added. Oh yea, and music stops when you go to the next area. But overall, original is safer bet as mods for HL1 will work with original, not Source remake. But Source one isn't bad either. Much better looking today, at 2014 year thanks to engine updates, while at time of release it didn't look like it added much.Deathmatch multiplayer part of remake was released after single-player part and comes by default with bundle on Steam... But let's just say, it's dead and not worth checking out.P.S. I approve ability to start at any chapter, easier to pick up.

Posted: October 25, 2014
												OMG!  I played it when it first came out and loved it.  Made me hooked for life.  Blue Shift, Opposing Force, 2, E1, E2, all of them.  Was bored, bought and d/l Source and... IDK if it is original bugs or new bugs but with out noclip I don't know how I'd get through some of the areas.  Oh, the vent is half an inch too short to just walk through but an inch too high off the ground to just crawl through.  But still, enjoying the some what updated graphics and ragdoll physics.  Just started tonight and played through to Blast Pit before deciding it was time for bed.But other than the few times I needed noclip, the game is as good as ever and makes me want to buy BS and OF and then move through HL2, E1, and E2 all over again on my next day off.  I would say get this game if you love the series but if are new, maybe stick to HL2?  Some will whine the graphics aren't amazing, and I do miss the gravity gun(Best gun in any game ever) but this classic is classic for a reason!

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												I like Half Life. It is one of my all time favourite FPS games. I believe it is because of Half Life why I really came to like this genre. I have been collecting FPS games ever since. I hate its Source conversion. Why? Because it is not a full conversion but simply an enhanced version with the Source engine's features. You have better water effects and you also have better shaders, lighting, shadows, etc.But essentially, it is the same as the vanilla version was. If you do not use high-res textures in a room then using modern water effects makes the game look strange. You can easily see how these things cannot work together.Black Mesa is a much better way to relive the experience Half Life gave us 15 years ago. It is a total conversion of Half Life and what is more important: it is free. Download and install that one or simply reinstall the vanilla game again.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 17, 2012
												For the record, my review of Half Life: Source can be applied to the original version of the game, except for a few asects that I touch upon regarding its transition to the Source Engine.By now, PC gamers everywhere have grasped full comprehension of Half Life. This monument of the videogame medium as a whole was VALVe Software's very first product; one that was by no means easy to produce, but was eternally rewarding. Half Life is still being played today and enjoyed by many people, and deservedly so. For it is one of those titles in videogame history that is recognized by many; even those who might have very little experience with the franchise or its modded stand-alone offsprings.Half Life puts the player in the shoes and HEV mark IV Protective System of everyone's favorite mute, crowbar-wielding, monster-slaying, marine-fighting theoretical physicist Gordon Freeman. The plot takes a humble beginning, as Gordon arrives to work--late--and prepares for what seems like a regular day at the Black Mesa Research Facility in the underground desert landscape of New Mexico. Perhaps a regular day, if not for the "deviation from standard analysis procedure." The player is let loose to briefly explore parts of the facility, allowing for a brief settlement before the experiment you are taking part of goes horribly wrong and all of a sudden that elevator you rode is out of order, that corridor you walked through is now covered in blood. That security  guard you talked to is trying to revive a scientist you had just run into 5 minutes ago, and that other scientist you talked to has turned into some weird mutant that is now walking towards you, though no longer with any interests of making small talk. Everything that the player had seen and gotten used to is now part of a horrific thrill ride; one that is action packed and will only get better from there.The game's story telling is absolutely fanstastic. It delivers a truly immersive experience by never leaving the first person perspective of the player and Dr. Freeman. It sacrifices cutscenes and cinematic mumbo-jumbo for first-hand experiences and uninterrupted gameplay. Said gameplay is very satisfying. There is a very good mix of firefights of varying intensity combined with puzzles and first person platforming. The puzzles can be a tad difficult at times, but just the right kind of difficulty to encourage perseverance and reward the player for their astuteness. Firefights are also quite fun; you start out making your way through waves of hostile inter-dimensional beings and later on fight none other than the few, the proud, the Marines, who pose quite an intimidating threat. The Marines really shine in the AI department, they're aggressive but smart enough to know when to retrieve. They have a sense of personal preservation unlike anything I have ever seen in any other videogame. They will try their hardest to kill Gordon, using any tools at their disposal, but they don't want to die, and will thus will make effective use of cover and defensive tactics. I would highly recommend purchasing the Source version of Half Life due to some added features such as much better particle effects, improved lighting and water effects, as well as the intergrated ragdoll physics. Those not interested in such added details could easily overlook the Source version and buy vanilla Half Life, seeing as how it is the same price on Steam as the Source version, but I would highly recommend getting this version for those who haven't experienced Half Life and are looking to get into it.You musn't dare call yourself a fan of Half Life or VALVe if you haven't played this game. Experience the original tale of a theoretical physicist trying to escape the Black Mesa Research Facility, perfectly remastered into VALVe's state of the art Source engine. It's a game you will not regreat putting your time and money into

Posted: January 1, 2014
												This is an epic game. If you consider yourself a true gamer, a gamer, or just someone who likes games, this goes without saying: Get this game. For the sake of this being considered a 'review' (not a bath of game-praise), I will give a slight reviewish thing.An epic game, with a satisfying-length story line, pretty good puzzles/obstacles, and also a pretty good fighting/shooting graphics and sound set. Keep in mind that I'm not going to say that much of anything is 'great', as this game is from a decade and a half ago. The regular graphics are ahead of their time (though not up to all modern standards), and the regular sound is good. This game is rated M (17+), but I've found it more to be a 13+ game since the graphics/blood/fighting is generally realistic, but is still old enough that it isn't in the "this is disturbing I just shot this guy and blood exploded everywhere" section. The aliens (enemies) in this game are generally unrealistic, and their blood isn't even red (more of a yellow-green hue), and the soldiers (humans, but still enemies) that you have to fight are, for the most part, completely covered in military armor and it's almost nothing like shooting another human. However, you are able to shoot allies (humans) as well, and if you do it's the same effect as the soldiers (blood flies lightly onto the nearest obstruction, character falls over, possibly shouts/groans in pain).That's pretty much all I've got. The jist of this review is: GO BUY THIS GAME. Okay? Good. Now leave me alone. ;)

content:
Posted: March 8
												I do not understand the critisiams that this port has recieved. Scrolling down to the comments section, it shows that people are butt-hurt about a '♥♥♥♥♥♥ port of the origanal' and plenty saying to 'buy the gold source version'. I think that these reviews are unjust. Now before clarifing, I have not purchased or ever played the origanal game. That said, HALF LIFE SOUCE is one of my favourite games of all time. Now people may be salty at me because I have never played the very first valve game, but the hatred towards it is that people have encounted lots of glitches. I however, have encounted none whatsoever in the many hours of playing. To clarify, I dont have a great PC. It has a crap Intel HD graphics, 8GB of RAM and a Intel Core i3. After second reviewing, I have found that the negative 'buy the origanal 1998 version' fanboys are from the last 30 days. I hope to counteract this, as I think it its embarressing to see one of my favouite games be downranked by meer mortals that don't know what a better version of a game is if they saw it. Because this game fixes,1: Better Models (Player Arms, Guns, Enemies, with only a few odd looking textures here and there that are bearable)2: Source intergration (You can play the maps in Garry's Mod and can play Half Life 2 levels if you know the console commands)And before people complain for me to get the origanal, I'd rather get Black Mesa than even attempting to play a game still stuck in 1998

Posted: June 23, 2012
												The first game to the renowned "Half-Life" Series. While it is an old game, it doesn't fail to entertain and make the player think. The campaign is fun, always fresh and seemingly never ending. I highly recommend this game to anyone considering getting it.

Posted: January 13, 2013
												Very immersive game. All sequences and character interactions happen in game and in real time. Creepy atmosphere and enemies. There are no major gaps in between areas, everything is sequential so you feel as if you're actually exploring throughout the entire game. Wide variety of weapons, alien weapons are inventive and unique. Puzzles are clever but platforming is clumsy. Long campaign for an fps. There's very little to the story, but the events that do occur are dramatic and keep you interested. Exploration is rewarded with secret areas that provide you with health, armor and ammo. Really solid old school fps and the start of a historic franchise. Deffiently worth it if youre looking for a unique fps. 8.0/10

Posted: December 18, 2013
												Half Life 1, one of Valve's first games to come to the Source engine.Common question I get asked, what's the difference between the "source" and "non-source" versions?Really, not a whole lot. Textures look the same, lighting, story, all that. Only things that you will be able to pick out is that the puzzles towards the end are wired differently. This is why I would have someone play the Source version over the goldsource one.Should you play it? Yes.Do you have to play this to call yourself a PC gamer? Yes.Is it really required or a "must play"? No.Many people would not be able to deal with the graphics, puzzles and "lack of heart pounding action". Sad to see people turn a title down due to those reasons.Speaking of graphics, you should be able to run this without problems. If you can't, get rid of Steam. This is as low as the bar gets set on detail and polygon counts.7.5/10

Posted: July 26, 2012
												Half-Life 2 may be a timeless classic, but the 1998 original needed a bit of a re-surfacing to hold up in a modern gaming environment. Half-Life: Source is the entire original game running on top of Valve's "Source" game engine. This gives the game much better lighting, physics and overall gameplay.Strangely, though, it does NOT include the higher(er) resolution textures and models update rolled-out by Valve and Gearbox as part of the release of Blue Shift. Without it, it's the same low-res graphics through Source-colored glasses.Fortunately a third-party has adapted the update for use in Half-Life: Source. I highly recommend downloading it to make this the definitive version of Half-Life. http://hds.newmail.ru/eng_download.html

Posted: August 6, 2016
												This is got to be one of my fav games of all time, the physics engine is awesome, and you can still go around beating aliens and scientists with a crowbar.Good things/pros about the game:New props.Cool physics engine, including ragdolls, boxes, guns dropping better, annoying xen controllers explodingBetter AI by what ive seen, they are not freaking stupid.New effects, including new water, hl2 blood, hl2 bullet decals.Cool start menu.Gmod content.Buttons!Half life deathmatch source included.Bad things/cons:Glitches include, tentacle can not kill npcs, gonarch sperm decal is missing, some times your flash light will cause this ugly mess all over your screen (usally on moving platforms.), there are possibly more that i havent encountered.I actually think its a great game.9/10 would wack scientists with crowbar again.(Some tips) To open the console you must right click the steam game select "launch options" type "-console". Then launch your game in order to have the console. ~theawesomepug

Posted: April 6, 2014
												It's somewhat ok as far as graphics goes. there are a lot of bugs and glitches and all that funtastic stuff. Something thats pretty strange is that the first time I started the game up and played it, all of the weapons and character models where completely different from the original Half-Life. The second time I started it up, the models were the same as the original the only difference to the game is just better textures and lighting (somewhat better). I have no idea what thats about or if anyone else is having this problem. Really the only thing that keeps me playing it is that you can turn on fast sitch weapons which is like really awesome.  I honestly dont like how this game looks and I recommed either getting the original Half-Life or just wait for Black Mesa to come out on Steam.

Posted: November 30, 2012
												Half-Life Source is a great idea on paper. A complete remake of the original Half-Life but in the Source engine with all the technological and graphical improvements that would bring. It is something a lot of us fans of the original would love to see. Unfortunately that is simply not what happened here.Half-Life Source only barely qualifies as being a port. They didn't change or upgrade anything, everything looks and feels the same and the only way you can tell it's a Source game is by looking at the game name.Graphics, animations, physics. Nothing has been improved to what Source is capable of. It is Half-Life running in Source sure, but if you can't tell the difference does it really matter?It is a great disappointment and a huge waste of money. If I had lost my copy of Half-Life back in the day I would have gladly shelled out the cash for a new copy so I could keep playing. But this isn't back in the day and this isn't the right Half-Life. You don't get the mods with this one.Stay away from this horribly rushed money grab. It's a waste of your time and your money. Go buy the original Half-Life instead or if you already own that, go play the Black Mesa mod. It's free and it doesn't suck.

Posted: July 14, 2014
												There are new physics and other cool stuff but it is very broken and they haven't done much effort to this remake. The weapons looked allright in the original Half-Life but in this they look like plastic. And i liked playing in thirdperson sometimes in the original but in this it's a mess. Just enable thirdperson in the console and see how Gordon has a crowbar, crossbow or a huge rocket launcher as a di*k. This may be cooler and better to some people, but for me... meh.After all the original was one of my favourite games back then and it still is, but THIS is just bad in my opinion. Buy the original Half-Life or download Black Mesa on the net for free which is a remake made right.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												I went into this having played hl2, but not the original. I was pleasantly surprised.The story is a bit odd, but still quite good. Freeman just gets thrown in the deep end, which if you look at it from one of two perspectives either makes everything terrifying or hilarious. This also provides a bit more backstory to the universe, which is good.A wide variety of weapons available. More so than hl2, I think, which is interesting and quite neat. It makes sense, given that this is set in a scietific research complex.I had some trouble getting my xbox controller to work with this, but I think using a keyboard/mouse setup works better. There's no real need for a gamepad here.Textures are about the right wuality for the age of the game. Not great by "today" standards, but still better than some games released about that time.The soundtrack in this is really good, but the voices in the game can sound a bit garbled and echo-ey at times.Despite the fact that this is a moderately old game, the source remake means that it has no compatibility issues with newer systems.If you've never played the original half life, then definitely buy this game. If you've not played either half life or half life 2, I would reccomend looking for a bundle on steam to buy that contains all of them.

Posted: December 18, 2013
												Half Life 1, one of Valve's first games to come to the Source engine.Common question I get asked, what's the difference between the "source" and "non-source" versions?Really, not a whole lot. Textures look the same, lighting, story, all that. Only things that you will be able to pick out is that the puzzles towards the end are wired differently. This is why I would have someone play the Source version over the goldsource one.Should you play it? Yes.Do you have to play this to call yourself a PC gamer? Yes.Is it really required or a "must play"? No.Many people would not be able to deal with the graphics, puzzles and "lack of heart pounding action". Sad to see people turn a title down due to those reasons.Speaking of graphics, you should be able to run this without problems. If you can't, get rid of Steam. This is as low as the bar gets set on detail and polygon counts.7.5/10

Posted: June 2, 2015
												Half-Life is one of the best and most influential fps games of the last few decades, and I think most would agree. Half-Life: Source is an update using Valve's source engine. While it's mostly the same, from level design, weapons, ect. there are minor differences such as updated water, better lighting and ragdolls. But this version has a lot more bugs than it's Goldsrc counterpart. Some that i came across were a floating scientist in the Anomalous Materials chapter, invisible barnacle tongues and the tentacle in Blast Pit not doing any damage (although that might not be a bug as I've heard that it was severely nerfed and can barely hit you). As for which version you should get for a first time player, it's kind of a toss-up. On one hand, Source looks slightly better, can be played in widescreen and has the updated water/lighting, but the original has much less bugs and has many more mods. It's really just up to you which you want. If you already have the original, though, there's not enough of anything new to justify a purchase. If you want a true source remake from the ground up, then buy BlackMesa.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												Half-Life was a game that was released in 1998 which was very old by today's graphic standards, but very great at it's time. Needing only a 500 MHz processor and a 16MB Direct 3D card this game was very much playable today, but since source came out (2004) the game's graphics engine was updated causing a 1.2 GHz Processor and a 64MB video card uping up the graphics, but still being beat by Half-Life 2's graphics later in the year.Gameplay:     The gameplay was very long and hours, even days to complete this 19 chaptered game in order to have the full experience, but I'm not going to tell what happens in the story like Half-Life 2's review because I'd ruin the story.     The enimies are harder in this game than Half-Life 2, but it's still able to be beat, but you will need to stratigize to beat this without taking tons of damage to yourself.Rating:     The final rating was 9.5/10 because it could've been less time consuming, but the story really counters that con anyways.Up next in reviews by Dead Kitty: Half-Life 2: Episode One

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Even so many years after it's release, this holds up really nicely and the Source update adds an extra pop to the visual splendor. But, visuals aren't everything in a game and Half Life understands it. Building on the puzzle mechanics of Doom and Quake, the puzzles are challenging, complex and they are quite accessible once you are involved in them. The combat mechanics are very immersive. The A.I. is really good and the enemies are challenging to defeat, especially the marines. Black Mesa is a delightful post-apocolayptic base that is a lot larger than initially expected. The voice acting is a little hoakey but it gives the game a more narritve feeling that was unique at the time. The sound effects are impressive and the enemies are well-designed. The amount of effort put into the game and the satisfaction you'd get from playing it is certainly admirable. It invigorated the FPS genre and its not hard to see why. :)

content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												The granddaddy of them all.Newer gamers might have a hard time visualizing how revolutionary this game was at the time, but it was one of the first truly narrative-driven FPS in gaming history. What's truly surprising is how well the game holds up - level design has aged somewhat (lots of corridors. LOTS of corridors), but the standards established in this game are still quite present today.This version of the game has been updated to use the Source engine for effects and physics, as well as the water modeling, so it's the best version of the game to purchase if you're looking for the best experience.Words cannot express how much you should own this game. It's as close to a mandatory purchase as you can get in gaming.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Half Life is a classic game, enjoyed by many in it's time, and even now. This however, is not exactly the original game, but more of a remake, built in the Source engine. In my review of the game I'm going to sum the whole game up, with an honest review on it's ups and downs - so let's get right into it.So let's start of with the storyline of the game. You stard of as a newly graduated Gordon Freeman on his way to work at the Black Mesa research facility. When you get to work, you have to get into a test chamber, where they are putting some kind of crystal onto a laser, but something goes wrong. The crystal messes with time and space and opens a portal to another dimension called Xen, through this portal, alien beings wreck havock in the facility. In the mean time the government here's of this, and decides not to help, but to kill everyone and everything involved. Nowadays, this story seems pretty generic, and is used in practically every sci-fi movie ever made, but this was made in 1998. Even still, I do think it was a bit lazy, but was a fun and exciting story nevertheless. The game includes many strategy based puzzles, and most things were very challenging, and some points I had to watch a YouTube tutorial on how on earth to complete parts. These puzzles were slightly annoying though at times, such as when the tram in 'On a Rail' and the conveyorbelts in 'Residue Processing'. Despite this, you always feel a sence of achievement after completing them, which is great.The original Half Life was a game that was made in 1998, and the graphics, while not horrible, are not great. This Source remake version was made in 2004, and the graphics are slightly improved, but I don't really think it matters which game you decide to play. I do think that the Source version however, was not ported over very well, as there were many scripted events that were broken, such as a security guard dying and so on. Also on the chapter, 'Residue Processing' which jumping from platform to platform, the screen will randomly show yellow, red and black splatters of colour across the screen, (see screenshot on my profile) which made the level almost impossible. Overall, I found this a great game to play, it was verey enjoyable, but extremely annoying and painful in certain chapters. I am going to give it a 7/10, purely because there was a lot of stuff that was broken, but aside from that I would reccomend you play it.

9/10 - may Gaben be with you.Hey, it's Half-Life. It was ahead of its time when it was released, but has it aged well? In terms of mechanics, not really. Graphics? Meh. The story, however - holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ I forgot how much I loved this game, and loved it with good reason too. The story is nothing short of amazing, and it's pretty obvious why people are begging for an edition to wrap everything up.If you want to get into the series, HL: Source is the way to go. Updated physics and a few graphical changes may not mean the biggest difference in the world, but it's enough to get noticed.Are there things I'd argue are flawed? Sure - but overall the plot is so enjoyable that you'll accept the game's age for what it is and still have a great time.

												This game was on my wishlist ever since I played the original Half Life, because I thought "Hey, Half Life with better graphics and physics? Yes please!". At that point, I had already played Black Mesa, the fan-made mod for HL2 which is essentially Half Life with better graphics, better than this even!Anyway, the Negatives:- I had some graphical issues related to the factory levels with the conveyor belts, when I turned my flashlight on and look at water, the whole screen would mess up- Gonarch at two points refused to move, meaning I had to skip the entire chapter (but I could do that easily via the menu, I didn't need to use commands!)- Even enemies refused to move sometimes- Xen in general was pretty broken and messy, so if that's your favorite chapter, be warned!- You can't gib ragdolls by hitting them anymore, nor can you move them around like in Half Life 2The Positives:+ The graphics and physics are really nice, everything feels more real than the original+ Destroying shelves and boxes and whatnot is way better and more fun+ The Flashlight was improved a LOT, as well as lighting+ Unlike Black Mesa, all the levels were exactly the same and the enemies behaved the same way as they did in HL1+ The Menu was improved a lot, as well as saving and loading and the whole GUI+ Movement is still the same, but it felt smoother to me and less clunky than in HL1All in all, I'd only recommend this game if you have played Half Life 1 already and want to play it with slightly better graphics. I wouldn't recommend it over Black Mesa if you want a Half Life game JUST for the graphics, only if you prefer the gameplay and feel of the old game and want to see it with a slight twist!If Half-Life 1 was a 96/100, I'd give this game a 88/100!

Posted: December 31, 2016
												Don’t get me wrong Half-Life is an amazing game, a masterpiece in fact that really stands the test of time. However I cannot in good faith recommend this version of the game. Considering this is supposed to be a remade version of the original game it has too many bugs to make it worth a buy. Now these are not bugs from the original game that they just didn’t fix, the game introduces NEW bugs and glitches. While I myself have never experienced anything game breaking or crashes (although I have heard of it happening). I must ask you what's the point in getting it if it's just worse than the original? Not to mention you're missing out on the huge mod scene of the original game.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												So why would I write a review for a game that's been out for like over 10 years and that is one of the greatest games on Steam? Well because I wanted to, but all other things aside this game is a great game hands down. Now I know it is a remake of Half-Life on the Source engine so it does do things a little bit differently sometimes from the original game. But the original game in a nutshell is basically that you are a scientist named Gordon Freeman on a project doing with specimens from a dimension called "Xen". You arrive at work late one day to test a rather unstable specimen, causing a sort of bridge between the dimensions of our world and Xen. You must fight through these monsters that teleports through this bridge and find out whats causing this catastrophic event. You must also fight the military who are trying their best to quiet this event by killing all of the monsters and the faculty of Black Mesa. Shooting is very satisfying in this game and it goes by the traditional "You are Hulk ♥♥♥♥ing Hogan and you can put 20 guns in your pockets". Which means you can carry stuff like pistols, smgs to rocket launchers and alien weapon things. Overall I give this game atleast 9.5/10 in my book. (If it was IGN I would give it a 20/10)

number of helpful: 13 of 25 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2011
												Half-Life Source is a slightly enhanced version of the 1998 classic. This supposed remake retains most of the original game's textures, models and animation but favours towards the better world effects available from the new Source engine of the time. Half-Life Source has a Havoc powered physics engine with enemies and objects obeying Newton's three laws, picture-quality water reflections and expanded scenary - now built as geometry rather than painted on backdrops. Also, the sound and presenetation now borrows heavily from Half-Life 2.My opinion of Half-Life Source is rather mixed, befuddled even. HL: Source feels very sloppily put together and thrown over. Valve could of and should of done a complete overhaul of the game. It's lukewarm reception from the many alienated players of the game led to the creation of Black Mesa Source, a total conversion set to unofficially reimagine the first game on the source engine. I implore you to wait for it instead. Otherwise, buy the original.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												Half LIfe is a great game, however, Valve did a sloppy job converting it to source. All of the models still retain their goldsrc materials and models, except now they have ragdoll physics. Also, thanks to the change of physics, there are certain parts that are harder to navigate. For example, in the chapter "Blast Pit" where you have to move the crates over the electrified water spill,  the crates hardly move at all thx to the source physics, making it almost guarenteed you'll be shocked.You're much better off playing Black Mesa Source.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Where do I even begin? Half-Life is easily my favorite game of all time. The controls are amazing. The story line is intriguing and is hugely expanded on by the large amount of sequels (still no Half Life 3 though). I love how you can talk to the AI in the game and convince them to follow you and help you fight, which can help save ammo, but also adds to the control you have. Honestly, thats what makes Half Life 1 great. Control! You feel like you have full control over the game. You are never fighting with it to get it to work. I hate to do this, but this is just one of those few games that I simply can't find any flaws with. I would honestly rate this game a 10/10. I often come back to this game and play through it again, and I will continue to do so in the future. If you haven't already, get yourself a copy and play this game!

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												HL:S doesn't offer much from the original HL beside the engine: ragdolls, water reflections and HDR support, but other than that, it's pretty bare. There is absolutely no new content, and many textures, models and maps are broken compared to the less-but-still broken version of the original Half-Life on Steam. If you want to only focus on the single player campaign, I suggest purchasing a disc copy of Half-Life online. However, if you want to jump in to a multiplayer server, purchase HL1 from steam, as HLS has a very dead multiplayer community. I think that the only upside of purchasing this is the ability to use its content in Garry's Mod. I am not a hater of HL, but this is a very bad buy.

content:
Posted: February 21
												Half life. One of the original games that almost every PC gamer has heard of or played. Half life puts you in the shoes of a scientist from black mesa. Gordan Freeman. A experiment goes horribly wrong and causes a "Ressonance Cascade" (not sure if i spelled it right) which allows aliens from another world (dimension or universe) to come to earth. The complex goes wacky and communications are out. Troops from the surface are coming down to rescue, as the science team says, but they plan to kill everyone who was involved.You must fight the troops and aliens, and make your way through their homeworld to defeat Nihilanth that controlls everything. Once Nihilanth has been defeated, all the vorticaunts and aliens are free. Gman then teleports you and gives you an offer. Work with him. Or be teleported to thousands of aliens and be slaughtered with the text that says. "You Died" You choose to work with him.On to Half Life 2...Pros:A classic CLASSIC game that every PC gamer should play.An amazing storyline that features some of the best moments in gaming history.Made by Valve.Cons:You havent bought it yet.Its a upgraded source code that's a little broken. Sometimes there are glitches but I havent come across any or crashes.10/10The. Best. Game. In. History

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												To make that people understand: Half-Life: Source is Half-Life. I enjoyed it because of that. Everything related to the original game is there, so, yeah, Half-Life: Source is a very good game in that aspect. Read that review to understand that HL:S could be a good choice for those that never played Half-Life - http://steamcommunity.com/id/vicrabb/recommended/70. For people like me, that played the original back then and many times after, the only real change seen is in the graphics but not in a spectacular way.Contrary to the title, the Source Engine, from Half-Life 2, isn't used at all. In reality, I feel like it's just the HD Texture Pack that was applied. And that pack was used for Half-Life: Blueshift, released in 2001. The mod-that-became-a-game Black Mesa is better if you want a real Half-Life with the Source Engine (though it's not sticking strictly to the original in terms of level design).I felt cheated. I don't remember if I bought the game or if I got it in a collector's edition of Half-Life 2 but I felt cheated there. I was expecting much better thing from Half-Life: Source and in the end, apart the fun that is still intact because it's Half-Life, I felt that the promise wasn't there.That's why I'm thumbing down this version of the game for people that love Half-Life and that would have preferred a better treatment for it. It doesn't mean that the game is bad in itself, I repeat, it's Half-Life. But I prefer to buy the original than that, that's all.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												As of today 2/27 this game is weird. It seems buggy as heckI dont really understand, from what Im reading the game was fine when it came out? But now its near completely broken I think. There are glitches EVERYWHERE and other weird going ons. I don't really understand how Valve could have broken so much in this game with updates?Technically speaking there are supposed to be very little changes, controls feel like you would expect in Source and are good and accurate when compared to how the old GoldSrc games control today which can take some getting used to but isn't bad. The way everything is rendered and shaders are diffrent, things look a bit more crisp but all models and textures are old. They actually look uglier to me than the standard HL1 non-hd models which I feel are the best to me visually. Ragdolls are added but thats really the only physics addition. Everything else from gibs to med packs uses the old HL1 physics where it simply falls or for gibs bounces and bounces. The water looks nice but does not fit in when everything around it looks cartoony. It ruins the dam scene for me atleast. Also they made some small changes in areas that I wasn't a huge fan of, mostly just looks related stuff and nothing big or something worth whining about. But of all the ports of HL1 I have played, which is only the PS2 and Source port, I like this one less. Atleast the PS2 version was objectively better than the original on PC when it came out in 2001. The orignal was released in '98. The Source port came out in 2004 and has none of the new content found in the PS2 version including the Coop expansion, Half Life Decay. I have not touched the Dreamcast version nor have I ever owned or played the Dreamcast aside from maybe one time at a family friends...maybe..its been probably near a decade since that. I also have not played the Linux or Mac ports but honestly I have no reason to ever want to us Mac OS. Linux is gaining ground though.Also the expansions are not present. Just basic Half Life 1.Present in this current version there is a huge problem with hit boxes on tanks, helicopters, and enemies of that type. The Gonarch also seemed to not take damage alot of the time when I was hitting it. Its just iffy and I want to say broken. Also with source some of the design decisions that were taken with Half Life 1 just seem awful. Vorts never missing even though it feels like your moving like Speedy Gonzalez just feels like bs and Xen still sucks. Yeah, Xen always sucks. I hate it so much until you get closer to the end and fight the nihlanth/final boss.But Half Life is still half life and its still fun. But this just isn't better in any way than the original aside from a few negligible graphics points. Black Mesa Source is what this game should have been, except for the fact that they did change alot of the game and removed some points and added others. This game should have just been Half Life but graphically updated with some small gameplay upgrades. Its just not what it should have been and falls short of the original.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												Now, I didn't encounter any game-breaking bugs that I've read some other people complain about, but since I need to complain about SOMETHING, here is my review.Hitboxes: They normally work fine. Except the time I wasted 10 bullets shooting a barnacle realising they all go through it. Had the same problem with houndeyes during the Blast Pit chapter. The real problem was with the Apache helicopter during the Surface Tension chapter where most of my rockets seemed to go through it, so unless you're lucky or skilled enough to hit it in a specific spot, you're ♥♥♥♥ed.The AI was really ♥♥♥♥in' dumb in some situations. I'm not saying that it was perfect in the original GoldSrc version, but how did they manage to dumb it down?Also, some textures and sound files were missing.tl;dr - Stick with the GoldSrc version.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												There's no doubth that this game is a classic, i remember playing it back in the 90's when it was just getting popular, magazines and gamers all across the globe were praysing Half Life for basically everything that could've been considered "good" in a game. Whether it was or not the gem that people claim even to this day to be, Half Life hasn't aged very well. The problem ironically doesn't last on it's graphics or even voice acting, the problem with Half Life it's it's game design, playing through the popular mod "Black Mesa" I can assure you that each and every single problem was solved on my part, the game was incredible, it had fantastic set pieces that played across perfectly as you played through the game having fun and confort all together, but this classic is just invaded with problems such as bad controls, difficult platforming, "sluggish shooting", and so on. Maybe you can get some enjoyment here and there if difficult first person platforming goes well with you, as it for me, it just tends to give me a headache.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												I'm sure this game was amazing at the time the original Half-Life came out. However, by todays standards this game leaves much to be desired. While I enjoyed the story telling from the eyes of the main character "Gordan Freeman", I found the actual gameplay to be disappointing for the following reasons:1. Movement is far too sensitive. Gordan moves very quickly. This wouldn't be a major concern except that this game includes plenty of platforming elements and this over-sensitivity makes certain parts of the game as well as ladders annoying and frustrating. 2. NPC's act glitchy. They will repeat grunt/pain noises repeatedly even when they are no longer being harmed. I have even seen some get stuck running in place without any obstacle stopping them. Enemy AI can be abused.3. Sound. The sound for the starting gun and crowbar are overly loud while the sound for other weapons such as the assault rifle are nearly impossible to hear.It's an old game obviously, and it shows. By todays standards I cannot recommend this. I am only continuing for the story so I can start Half Life 2.

By todays standards I cannot recommend this. I am only continuing for the story so I can start Half Life 2.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Half-Life was an amazing game back in 1998. It's one of the few games that I remember playing, and completing during that time. I would recommend Half-Life to anyone who hasn't played it, but for those who have, it just doesn't hold up over time. It's just not the same as playing it back in the 90s. Then again, many things aren't.This source version of the game, doesn't do anything for me. The graphics are better, but that makes the game... "less scary". There is way too much lighting. Areas that used to be dark, and spooky, are now brightly lit, and the emenies aren't scary at all, because the newly done models, just don't have the same effect as the older, darker models.I remember nearly running from the room when the game originally came out, because it was just too scary. The new graphics, and brightly lit models, just put me to sleep.I find this source edition to be even less interesting, because it gives you instant access to every level in the game. So there is no challenge anymore. There is no reason to play the game from the start (there is no reason to save), because you can just pick any level you want, and start there. That might be fun for some people, but as soon as I saw that was an option, I was instantly turned off. Sure, this is an option, and you don't have to play it that way, but just due to the fact that the levels are all open, is a turn off for me.If you're looking for this game, because you think it's going to take you back to the 90s... Don't be surprised when it doesn't have that same effect.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												It's a garbo port. Simply put, they just redid some of the textures/water and called it a day, failing to account for how the small differences between Goldsrc and Source could completely change the game. Twice Source's slightly different jumping physics led to me ending up in areas of the levels that rendered them unwinnable (and not obviously unwinnable for a good 5-10 minutes, either), the first boss is completely broken and can't even hurt you, and the new soldier AI makes the soldiers go from "reasonably difficult" to "lord help me I'm being swarmed and have nowhere to go". In the end, a slight graphical touch-up just isn't worth dealing with the myriad of problems this port introduced.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
A classic game that does not need introductions.This is a classic that defined its genre, and 16 years after its release is still very enjoyable.The "source" version of it is a reimplementation of the original game on Valve's then new engine and offers a slightly better graphic experience, although much of the visual artifacts have been left unchanged, with low-count polygons models and low-res textures.In terms of gameplay one has to think to how computers and games were back in 1998.  Seen with modern eyes some of the game mechanics are repetitive (especially towards the end, where increased difficult = more badass monsters from previous levels to kill), but again, if you are going to play this game now you should definitively approach it as a movie-goer would approach a black&white film from the 40's.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												Having heard some good things about Half-Life, I finally purchased it one day. As a huge fan of FPS games, I wanted to like this game.Sadly, I didn't. At least not as much as other FPS games I've played, such as Doom, Quake and Unreal. Those games are better than this on many levels. For one, they didn't have annoying platforming with mechanics that just barely function. They also didn't include frustratingly difficult human enemies that drain your health from 100% down to 5%, sections where you had to run and jump through enemy hordes and traps because the game suddenly decided to not give you any ammunition, or areas you couldn't get out of if you happened to find yourself lost in them.Half-Life, on the other hand, did include all of those things, and those are the reasons why I only enjoyed it so much. While the game shines in its presentation, it falls short on its gameplay, at least for me. Unless you're into stuff of the aforementioned sort, I can't say I'd recommend Half-Life either.
