number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												This is one of the best games I have ever played. Half-Life is a classic that should be played by anyone who appreciates FPS's. In fact, it's your obligation to play this game, because it was the first to do so many things in video games. There are many games that have heavily leaned on the format, gameplay and story telling strategies of this game. The game is very dated, and it shows, but Valve did implement the Source engine which gives it a more polished, free-flowing look. I was able to disregard the dated graphics, because I knew that this was such an original and classic game. The first half hour of the game is brilliant, because nothing is really happening, but there is an ere tone and feeling that lets you know that something's not right. Some subtle foreshadowing occurs when some of the computers break, and a scientist says the power is going to be switched on to 105%. It's show-not-tell things like this that make the game so gripping and immersive. It's something we don't seem to see in many games anymore. Anyway, during the first three quarters of the game, you're running around, collecting new weapons, killing aliens, and soldiers sent there to kill you, (a perfectly executed plot twist) solving puzzles, picking up more of the story, riding on rails, launching rockets, blowing up helicopters, storming military bases, navigating mine fields, annihilating green, bangy, tentacle thingies, electrocuting, and blowing up giant, blue flamethrower monsters; the list can go on and on. Basically, you're just having a lot of fun. The constant change of objectives really keeps the player immersed in the game. You never feel like you're repeating the same things over and over again. This is a staple in the Half-Life franchise. Once you start getting bored of something, it changes it up so that you're doing something different and more exciting. The pacing in this game is also phenomenal. It usually goes in the order of: Action event, slow puzzle event, action event slow puzzle event, with some events that feature action and puzzle at the same time, and story exposition sprinkled around and mixed in through everything you do. It's constant fun that never frustrates you or makes you feel cheated. The subtle rise in difficulty is more subtle than, you know, just changing the color of the monster. It's realistic, and makes you feel the tension rising around the Black Mesa facility. The first three quarters of the game are nearly flawless.In my opinion, the only downside to this game is the last quarter where you play in the alien world, Xen. This segment of the game really breaks up the immersion. The gravity is toned down, so everything you've gotten used to in the first part of the game is scrapped for a floaty, hard to manoeuvre, way of moving. It's also very slow. From a story telling perspective, it's mind blowing, but from a gameplay perspective, it's quite dull and frustrating. During the chapter Xen, you're just platforming, trying to figure out where to go. Gonarch's Lair was just an annoying, frustrating, slow paced boss fight, But the REAL kicker was interloper. I hated this level. It was way too long, way too difficult, way to confusing, and way too frustrating. If there was an enemy I could have removed from this game it would be those flying baby thingies, but they were everywhere here and they would respawn all the time! There's never enough health, energy, or ammo for you, so you have too eek by in this extremely hard level. In most levels, if it was hard, it was because you needed to change your strategy. It was your fault if you died. But in this level, there are just way too many overpowered enemies. You're trying to save your health and running out of ammo, and BOOM! You're hit with ten million, flying babies, and bee shooting giants, while being hit with vortigaunt lightning from every corner. The only way to get through this level is to set the difficulty to easy, and die a million times before you memorise where each enemy will be and when he will attack. That's no fun. That's just drudgery. Nihilanth was just a giant version of those annoying flying babies. Great. To be honest, he was just mediocre. Okay, I do hate how all the Zelda bosses, for example, have huge shiny targets on them that show you exactly where to place a bomb or shoot an arrow, but at least they help you figure out how to defeat it. In Nihilanth, I had no idea how to defeat the monster. shooting it did nothing, and it kept sending me away to these weird caves by throwing portals at me. I was completely lost. I had to go on youtube and see how it was done before I even knew how to kill it. It was still too hard too kill it though. If you play it the way it was intended and jump up onto those cliff things, it's really hard, and he will keep sending portals at you. If you're cheap like me and just hid behind the spiky rocks, then it's easier, but it's painfully repeditive and tedious.Boss fights in this game were not good with the exception of the green tentacle thing. I will cut it some slack though, because it was kind of a 90's thing to have bosses in your games, and this was a very hard game to put bosses into.In the last chapter, you're given a monologue from the mysterious G-man, who you may have noticed stalking you throughout the game. He makes you go through a portal, and then the credits hit, reminding you how good the soundtrack in this game was.All in all, Half-Life was a classic, and should be played by anyone who likes video games. If you like steam you should play this game to show your respects to Valve. It was the first game they made. Half-Life rose to my personal favorite video game franchise after the Metroid Franchise was ruined by Other M. Anyway, just play this game. You have no excuse not to. Oh, and Gabe, PUHLEEEZZZE MAKE HALF-LIFE THREEEEE!

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												I have played the game for about 2 hours now. This is probably the first time since the late 90's/early 00's since I have played the original Half-life. Its amazing how well the game still holds up to this day. Its easily much more fun then most shooters on the market, and I would argue that its also better then Half-Life 2. As for the changes in this verison, the game comes with the HD pack that originally shipped with the Blue-Shift expansion pack, and improved ragdoll (did the original even have ragdoll?), as well as realistic water and slightly better lightning. Explosions sprites have also been replaced with half-life 2 like explosions. Overall I would say this game is considerably better then the original Half-life. I would also like to mention that this game is worht playing even if you have Black mesa. The reason is that the game just feels so much different then black mesa does. The graphic style is completely different. You can't really compare the 2. Overall I am giving this a 9/10.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												1998, I was 18, Id been weened on the Spectrum, then the Amiga.  I got my PC in 1996 and for two years played pretty ropey demos, and sometimes good stuff, like Theme Park.  Then I picked up half life.  Lifechanger.What can I say?  The intro scene setting, the journey in on the monorail, the voice welcoming you to your working day, the sound design... THE SOUND DESIGN.  I think thats what got me.  Im a music producer by trade and even 18 year old me was blown away by the score, and sound effects.  The levels on Xen, the sounds made, the voice of the Nihilanth, it was all too perfect.  This game holds up today, yep, graphically its a little jaded, but i still play, and I mean this source version, not the Black Mesa update.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												Half-Life: Source is half-baked and woefully in need of a hefty extra dash of Source. It's a shame. Pushed to pick my Desert Island PC game, I'd sadly set aside the likes of Deus Ex and Combat Mission in favour of the orginal Half-Life. It was an astonishing development in the art of video gaming and there's been nothing quite like it since in terms of story-telling flair, variety and visceral excitement.Applying "Source technology" to Half-Life should, therefore, have been a masterstroke.Sadly not. It looks barely any different.Here's what to do: forget Half-Life: Source, download the Black Mesa remake, and prepare to be astonished all over again...

												Unlike the original Half-Life, which is in my opinion the best game of all time, Half-Life: Source is a buggy piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥with broken AI, broken hitboxes, sentences.txt written by an intellectually disabled dead squirrel, broken weapon recoil, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ standard HL2 user interface, ear♥♥♥♥♥♥inducing SteamPipe save-load freezing which often results in the game crashing, poor optimization, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ (optional) HD weapon models that look like they were ripped straight from Gamebanana in 2002, broken multicore rendering which causes strange graphical glitches in certain areas of the game and it uses the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ default Source 2K4 movement system and footstep sounds along with poorly implemented Half-Life 2 water textures and HL2 barrel models that don't fit with the rest of the game. It has no redeeming qualities whatsoever compared to the original game and it should be removed from the Steam store because it's just the same game with more bugs and better water.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												Has NOT aged well... I really can't stand it. Yes, this game is important to history, so you should at least try it at some point, but I don't think it's worth anything anymore. At this point, it's a relic that represents a landmark in gaming history more than it is a game. My main gripes are its absolute adherence to old-school shooter design with the modern (as we know it) narrative design layered over it. It was revolutionary at the time, but so many games have come along and done what it did so much better that it's impossible to look back on this and still say it's good on it's own terms. Maybe Black Mesa will change my opinion on it (especially if they put in PROPER full controller support), but until then? Find some way for a friend who already loved Half-Life to let you play it instead of buying it for yourself is what I have to say.

												One of the best FPS games I've ever played.Level design is good. content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												How to start...Half life 2 is an AMAZING series and it really is a great series including Ep. 1 and 2 as well.Half Life on the other hand, in my opinion, is ridiculously convoluted and difficult for it's own good.I have spent hours, LITERALLY hours of my life trying to make this game function correctly. multiples upon multiples of times I have died the exact moment a loading screen comes up, the downside to this is that once those screens come up, it autosaves with no warning. This means, if you're like me anyway (Not saving every 5 seconds), you will lose ALL of your progress and have to restart. It is also extremely difficult to figure out the path you are meant to take to complete your task out of Black Mesa, this isn't exactly a downside as older games are all mostly like this and won't just hold your hand, which I am a fan of. Personally, I do not recommend playing this if you value your sanity and sleep, as you will be losing the entirety of both while you try to fight the game just to finish it.That being said, this game does add to the amazing story and universe of Half Life/Half Life 2 that we all love as well as the FPS mechanics are perfect and defined an era of games.I give Half Life a 4/10, it just doesn't hold up well at all and is rather dated

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												The crappy port of the original/former greatest PC game of all time. Get 1998's Half-Life instead. This is Half-Life with a ton of additional bugs (thanks to broken Steampipe updates and some original poor porting),new water textures, added ragdolls, barely improved skyboxes, motion blur, broken AI, screaming scientists,glowing floors and bloom, (which doesn't work). Not good! And whaddya know the port was done by Gearbox. Some of the alterations to the gunplay and weapon properties already affect it negatively but what's most shocking is how buggy it is and how many lenghty loading zones that weren't present in the original Half-Life have been added. Some load zones even intterupt the music just as it starts. The 2013 Source Pipe update didn't do it any favors either and in fact making it far worse and unstable to boot! There is a 50/50 chance the game will fail to start for players for some unknown reason. Stranger yet is one level is even uglier than it was in the 1998 original shockingly by making the map look far less expansive: 


AFTER 
Community Created Artwork for Steam Artwork
By: GuyOnAChair

			Half-Life: Source Surface Tension		





AFTER AFTER 
A Screenshot of Black Mesa
By: GuyOnAChair




(The last picture is from Black Mesa's faithful remake.)If you've ever seen a picture of a scientist floating above a chair then the picture was in fact taken from Half-Life: Source as that bug never happend in Half-Life 1998. Oh and here's an example of one of the many bugs ingame:http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=696258149Note the lack of sky and the fact that my HEV suit has dissapeared. Not to mention that when a game released on the Source engine is prone to crash more than a game released on 1998 on a modern PC you know something  has gone awry. There are also instances where new Half-Life 2 textures are right alongside badly ported Half-Life 1 textures leading to a George Lucas remastered effect. Not to mention some broken scripting, missing music and textures shining as bright as the sun in dark rooms. The orginal runs flawlessly and works in widescreen and in terms of gameplay still holds up quite well with the obvious (Doesn't bother me.) exception being the graphics which are more than a little dated. Oh but of course you could always just toggle to use the HD models instead. If you wan't a version of Half-Life with subtle improvements to atmosphere, immersion and better graphics and that actually take full advantage of the Source engine get Black Mesa instead. In fact both the Black Mesa mod (Black Mesa retail/Steam edition runs on Source 2013 and recently so did Half-Life:Source.) and Half-Life: Source run on Source 2007. Half-Life: Source was so crummy that we have it to thank for inspiring people remake Half-Life on the Source engine themselves. If Counter Strike: Source was just 1.6 visuals rendered on the Source engine with a plethora of new bugs and weird changes to the gameplay (Unlike Counter Strike: Source which is a whole new game.) you would have pretty disapointed wouldn't you? This doesn't do much of note visually and adds longer loading to really hammer the nail in the coffin. Oh and Source SDK doesn't work with it either. This is pretty useless and I don't reccomend getting it in the year 2016 where as I would still whole heartedly reccomend the 1998 original or even the unfinished Black Mesa.My review for BMS can be seen here:http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/362890My review for Half-Life: Source Deathmatch can be seen here:http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/360

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I highly recommend this product if you want to venture Half-Life 1's campaign in Garry's Mod, with the ability to spawn every one of your favorite Xen aliens/monsters. If you're a fan of the Half-Life franchise and wan't to relive the gameplay of the first game in a polished and new light, then you're better off installing Black Mesa: Source. Compared to the original version, Half-Life: Source offers absolutely nothing new to the table. The game basically lives up to its name, it's Half-Life 1 imported and playable on the Source Engine, nothing special.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Now, it's an AWFUL game. Half-Life WAS an OKAY game, for it's time. Now this isn't because of age I have multiple reasons.*THE STORY*I blew up something and now there's aliens?If the story was padded with interactions with characters it would be alright, but you have no sense of direction. I literally spent the game shooting things and aimlessly pressing buttons. I'm not a stickler but this was done horribly. I just walked, shot, pressed buttons, jumped, and turned wheels. The story is just awful in the first. The security guys are useless as well. They just say stuff that doesn't matter, giving you vague objectives. What kills the story is that everyone and everything feels lifeless. You can hate me but it's true. The game is LITERALLY 13 HOURS OF SHOOTING♥♥♥♥♥♥AND PRESSING BUTTONS WITHOUT ANY PERSONALITY. No one was funny, no one was cool, no one was my friend. It was a chore to play this game. Hell ,if Gordon was suppose to be an extension of the player why do we barely interact with people. THEY JUST SAY "SURE I'LL RISK MY LIFE 4 U♥♥♥♥♥IT BIG BOI!!!"*THE GAMEPLAY*Oh god, even on easy everything was a bullet sponge while *YOU* THE GUY IN A POWER SUIT DIES IN LIKE 4 HITS!Killing♥♥♥♥♥♥didn't even feel satisfying, it got so boring that I turned on god mode the last 4 chapters. IT'S NOT FUN AT ALL. THIS PIECE OF *BLEEP* IS STILL BUGGY AS ♥♥♥♥ ON MY NVIDIA GTX 640 INTEL I7 QUAD CORE AND 16 GIGS OF RAM! There was screen tearing and crashing. What. The. ♥♥♥♥. It didn't do much except the EXCEPTIONAL PHYSICS ENGINE! The gameplay remained tedious with a few sequences of platforming and escorting people, that is too far apart and too far in between. How does it hold up today?It doesn't.I give Half-Life Source a 4/10.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												Overall a fun game, but it is very plain.  It only took me 18 hours to complete, but it had become boring after only 8.  I finished just for the sake of completeness. Though I guess I'm not a big shooter game fan to begin with, it just seemed like the same thing over and over again after a while.  Shoot this, shoot that.  The storyline sequences happening in "real-time" instead of having cutscenes was pretty novel, and it was a snippet of a neat story involved, but other than that this is just a dusty old historical piece.  I would only recommend it to hardcore FPS fans who want to relive a milestone of the genre.  But even then... why not just get Black Mesa?Oh, I should note that I had a bug early in the game, before any real action had taken place.  I couldn't walk through a door.  I had to work it out a using a cheat to "no-clip" through the door.  It ran just fine from then on.

content:
Posted: January 13
												Short version: Go buy Black Mesa. If you want to know why this game is a ♥♥♥♥ing joke, by all means, proceed. HL Source is the only bad Valve game ever released. It's honestly unbelievable how awful and fundamentally broken this one is, Valve managed to take their most iconic game- not to mention the one which launched their company to stardom, and absolutely deprive it of quality. For 10 bucks, what do you get from HL Source? An unplayable mess full of broken scripted sequences, broken NPCs, unbalanced weapons and damage systems, infuriating glitches, levels so broken you can't win, levels so broken you can't lose, just a total disaster. I hate to repeat myself so much, but this game is a broken mess. Even the Garry's Mod content is pretty lackluster, you'd be better off with a free mod like Half Life Renaissance. Oh, and for fans of the HD models that came with Blue Shift, don't even bother. For one they seem to be modified from the original release (why bother with such tiny changes?) and most importantly, the models are incomplete showing wireframes, and even the sounds on the guns like the M4 and SPAS-12 are missing altogether. The "selling points" of HL Source include a HL2 style chapter select, improved Source Engine lighting, HL2 style water, and ragdoll physics. That's it. For ten bucks. How could Valve have gone so wrong? Counter Strike Source and Day of Defeat Source offered complete Source remakes of their predecessors, so why are we stuck with this awful port instead of a real remake, like the mod Black Mesa? And more importantly, why hasn't Valve even bothered to make this garbarge at least functional? It's full of little distracting mistakes any HL series veteran will notice immediately. Just a mess.I will say the Deathmatch multiplayer is fun. You can actually get this in a pack of other Source multiplayer titles without having to get HL Source. DMS has a lot of the same problems as Source, but luckily the abudance of great community made maps makes it worthwhile.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												While I can see why the game was so groundbraking back in 98 it just doesn't hold up well.There are some good moments in there but for every good one there is one frustrating and two boring ones. Visually game doesn't look good. It is not a matter of old graphics but lack of atmosphere and artstyle. Areas look quite similar to each other for the most part.Gameplay is just painful. Half-Life exists in this awkward spot between old-school shooters and new Modern Military Shooters. You move fast and have access to many weapons at once (they are quite a boring tough) but many of your enemies especially in the late game use attacts which can't be dodged. It gets really annoying really quickly. Also first person platforming. And movement. Gordon slides all the time. You will die repeatedly by falling off something.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												This version of Half Life is inferior on a gameplay standpoint. While the Source Engine may improve some sections and add very little to the game, the whole expeirence is almost the exact same thing like the 1998 original, except with one horrible addition that practically breaks the game at most parts, slippy jumping physics. While it may not be noticable at first, the crane platforming section early on in the game becomes extremely infuriating and tedious because of the slippy jumping in this port.The original had tight jumping which made platforming work very well, but here it can make new comers hate the platforming of Half Life; which already has a mixed reputation from some audiences. Save the money from this version of the game and just buy the original 1998 version. You are not missing much here, if anything for that matter. If you want Half Life Source that a certain group of modders envisioned back when this was released, then check out Black Mesa. If you are in some dire need of Gmod models and whatnot, then wait for a Steam Sale to pick this up.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												By the time I picked this game up back in 2004 it was already a old game, but HL is single handedly responsible for me getting back into gaming, and switching from console to PC.Back when I was a kid I always prayed that one day they would make a videogame that was like a virtual reality where you could move around a real enviornment and interact with objects. Prior to Half-Life I had only played Woffstein3D and doom for PC. Doom was great but it wasn't really interactive or very realistic. Half-Life was a dream come true and it will always be my favorite PC game of all time.For all those youngling's out there who grew up with Call of Duty and the like, you probably won't like this game. The graphics are old now, and the pace is slow. However if your still relatively new to gaming then please do yourself a favor and try it. Hell it even has a training room for those who don't have experience controlling a character in first person.The only difference between HL and HL source is that source has slightly improved lighting and textures in certain areas. Its worth getting over the stock version, but then again if you really want to experience the game as it came out back in 1998 then sure get the original.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2012
												I finally got around to playing the original Half-Life, wanting to expand my knowledge on the universe that Valve had created.This is possibly the worst Valve game I have yet played. It has aged poorly. I guess if I had the fortune of playing it upon release I would appreciate it more, but I just can't understand how it managed to garner so much praise back in 1998. Perhaps there were some major changes that affected gameplay when they released the Source version in 2005?The AI is completely broken. You can edge around corners and slowly pick off immobile enemies by shooting their feet. If they can't see you their AI won't kick in. Pretty terrible mechanics. Apparently the AI was taken from Half-Life 2 when HL: Source was released. It doesn't show it.The controls are way too twitchy. It's almost impossible to succesfully climb down a ladder without dying the first time. You often go sliding off edges as if Gordon's feet are made of ice. It was certainly a frustrating experience.There is also absolutely no story or character development. None. You are Gordon Freeman, a scientist. You open a portal to another dimension. You close the portal. The end. Everyone you meet along the way is disposable and has no distinguishing features or names.There is no explanation for any of what is happening, there is no lead up to Half-Life 2. The reasons for the military presence are not explained, neither is the fact that they are replaced with Combine forces in the sequel, however many years later.The only connection between Half-Life and Half-Life 2 is Gordon Freeman and the G-Man. That's it. The only recurring enemies are the headcrabs and Vortigaunt, the latter of which are apparently on your side for some reason. Who knows how they ended up on Earth if the portal was closed.This was an amazingly empty experience, void of any story or sense of progression. I understand that was Valve's and, especially, Gabe Newell's intentions, but it just doesn't sit right with me.I know my opinion will go against the grain and, while I did enjoy the game overall and appreciate how it is placed within the Half-Life universe, I still can not overlook the many smaller flaws that become overbearing during gameplay. I have to wonder if these issues exist in the original Half-Life game or if they are exclusive to the Source version.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												Is Half-Life truly the greatest game of all time? I can answer that question with one word.No.My friend had been pestering me for months to play this game. I had heard so many wonderful things about it, “It’s the greatest game of all time”, “It has an amazing story” are just two of the many great claims I’ve heard about this game. I’ve got to say, I’m extremely disappointed.After launching the game, I’m greeted by some pretty abysmal graphics. The original game was released sometime around 1996, so poor graphics are to be expected in the original version of the game. What’s not to be expected is for there to be poor graphics in the remake/remaster of the game (Half-Life Source). If the graphics are this bad, I might have well just played the original version.At first I put this aside; a game with bad graphics doesn’t always equal a bad game. I decided proceed through the “tutorial” area until I actually reach the real part of the game (in which you get your first weapon). I was quite frustrated to find out that I had to use a crowbar as a weapon, which in my opinion is quite a bad design decision. You are going to get a gun later in the game anyway, so why not just provide a gun earlier in the game? Another thing I can't work out is why did they put glasses on the main character? It doesn't seem very badass for the main character to wear glasses.I then struggle to play though the game due to the dry story and boring combat mechanics. I honestly don’t know why everyone thinks the story to this game is so amazing. A science laboratory gets filled with aliens and you need to escape that laboratory. The story doesn’t get any more complicated or in-depth than that.You also see a man in a suit from time to time. I don’t see the point in this since you never get the chance to fight him. He is clearly the bad guy in the game, but instead of fighting him at the end of the game, you just speak to him instead. What a disappointment.Take my advice. Save your money and spend it elsewhere.

												Honestly, you shouldn't be playing this game unless you want the "full Half-Life story experience". It really hasn't aged well, first-person platforming is horrible, and the enemy AI has pretty terrible power scaling (any time an enemy is in your field of view it just aimbots you, meaning you can't actually have fights without taking massive damage). It's a good history lesson, but I don't think this game deserves high reviews. Play HL2 instead.

Posted: July 17, 2012
												Which is better, Half-Life or the Source version? Well, that depends on what your willing to deal with between the two. Half-Life Source looks quite a bit better than the origanal with its water effects, motion blur, and fixed box-pushing machanic. However, unlike the origanal, Source DOES NOT have an auto save! So you could progress throu the entire game, die right at the end, and start over at that damn long tram ride. Another thing to mention is the enimies just love to get right in your face, so be perpared to use you shotgun alot. As long as your willing to deal with that, and have a habit of pressing the F6 key, then go ahead and get Half-Life Source. Otherwise, just stick with regular Half-Life.*Note: In case anyone hasn't played a Valve game before, F6 is the manuel save.*****

												In a nutshell, this is Half-Life ported to the Source Engine including all the benefits the engine provides.  I chose to play through this one instead of the original because of the more advanced engine.  Gordan Freeman must fight his way out of the Black Mesa facility after a terrible experiment release creatures from another dimension into our dimension.  The Government sends troops to silent the experiment and all survivors within the facility.  It feels like a classic FPS such as 007: GoldenEye, which is good then again it is from 1999 and Valve's first game.  There isn't much reason to play this other than to learn of the history before Half-Life 2.  For 1999 standards I give it a 9/10, for its 2004 release 8/10.  Right now, a 7/10.

Posted: February 24, 2016
												Still playing this game in 2016. My main problem with Half-Life is that I've started playing this game several times but I never managed to finish it. This time I intend to complete this game. This is probably what I like about this game, even after many attempts of trying to finish it I have not given up the hope to finally do it and I never got bored of it.This game looks very stable, despite one level where I experienced texture pop ups. Posted: February 26, 2016
												Graphics and Bugs:This game is an original Half-Life but on the source engine. Which means better graphics and less bugs and glitches. On the original Half-Life the sound could not be heard sometimes, here its fixed. But really rare there is a ladder bug when you jump on ladder and it knocks you off (requires restart) and basically thats it.Difficulty and genre:Luckily the game was developed a long ago, when the story was not very important, when developers were adding much more action than in modern games. Yeah of cource it has story, and events but nothing complicated. The athmosphere and action are something to enjoy in this game. It is difficult even on easy difficulty to find where to go, or just complete the chapters (some take 1-2 hours). But I would call it ''challenging'' instead of ''omg sucks'' or ''too hard''The start and end of game:The start was clear, whole chapter spent on introduction which is kind of needed to be done. The end had some kind of mystery, and some questions could be asked. Has two endings, and you can only hope what Gordon is going to choose.Rating:I would give this game 9/10. First played in 2015, and it is a game for all the times!

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Is there a gamer on the planet that doesn’t know Half-Life yet? Would we have Steam today if Valve had not made Half-Life? Good questions but I’m really supposed to write a review about this game. The atmosphere is dense, story compelling, action super fun and challenging, controls responsive, and game world buzzing with weird lifeforms. Half-Life sort of faces the same conundrum as Crysis as in the sections where you fight the human soldiers feel a lot more fun than blasting the aliens. In this game, though, the difference isn’t that huge. The aliens are menacing but you feel like a badass when you get them to submit under your shotgun fire. The only thing that really made me wanna drop the score is the fact that the difficulty level on the game is super cheap. And by cheap I mean you’re gonna die a lot. You can save whenever you want but that doesn’t help too much when you gotta perform a stunt obstacle course where a single wrong move makes the difference between a live Gordon Freeman and a dead Gordon Freeman. You need to be a bit of a masochist to play this game, but if that’s not a problem, you’re gonna love every second of it.

Posted: November 18, 2015
												If you are unfamiliar with Half-Life, it is an fps in which you play as a physicist who has to survive an alien incursion in an underground research facility. This is a port of the original Half-Life to the Source engine.The gameplay is varied, containing combat, puzzle solving, and platforming. The story is interesting; however, the player must pay attention in order to get some of the more obscure plot points. There is plenty of enemy variety and a large number of weapons to use against them.There are a few negatives: the platforming can require many attempts to get past certain sections and there is a large difficulty spike near the end.The differences between Half-Life and Half-Life Source are improved water graphics and physics, the addition of ragdoll physics, better lighting, and 3D skyboxes.Overall Iwould give this game a strong recomendation of 9/10

Posted: September 23, 2012
												In all honesty I would recommend this with or without Source, but it is a game for those who want to go back to where it all began and still be able to see decent graphics. Anyhow, it's normally a game that one would play for the storyline, which is very well-constructed and built-upon reinforcedly by its sequels. Of course, then there's the gameplay, which is done splendidly, you have control over thirteen different weapons by the beginning of the Lambda Core chapter, which, though rather far into the game, is a landmark in the series. These weapons include two laser guns and an alien organ with infinite ammo, so there is plenty of science fiction to go around in the story, along with detail to explain it. The graphics are done beautifully for a game of its time, with or without the source engine added, and make for a spectacular exploration through the Black Mesa facility, and eventually another dimension known as XEN.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												If you want to play HL in the source engine, than this is THE version for you! They don't realy change to much of the game. But some graphical things are pretty much improved. Some puzzles also include a brand new twist because of Source's physics engine. The body's are now fully dynamic and so is the flashlight. You're now able to add motion blur and other new graphical stuff that makes the game look a lot better. They also keep the tone and mood from the first game by including all of the original textures. But some of the sounds (Like the foodsteps) are directly from HL2 witch makes the game sound alot better. And if you're a fan of the HD content the original Half-Life had, they included all of those moddels into this version. Witch makes it look even better. So if you're a HL fan, this game will stand nicely in your game library.p.s: Sorry for my english. Its not my main language.

Posted: September 30, 2015
The black sheep of the Half-Life seriesFirst of all, Half-Life is a great game. Everyone knows that. I don't need to bother describing Half-Life's gameplay in any detail. Long story short, I loved the game then and I still do. Its influence on the industry is virtually unparalleled and indirectly led to the creation of Steam in the first place!However, Half-Life: Source is a disappointment with a misleading title. I say "misleading" because having already played Counter-Strike: Source and Day of Defeat: Source, I expected this game to be a full HD remake of the original, with proper models and textures. Instead, all we got was the original 1998 models and textures running on the Source engine. We didn't even get the polygonal upgrades that Half-Life Blue Shift received. Sure, the physics and lighting are modern, but it's hard to notice when everything else is blocky and jagged. It makes this game seem pointless especially when the original 1998 game is still available and has a much larger community. It's such a shame - I'm sure this game would've made a killing selling at full price if it were a proper HD remake. At least I didn't directly pay for this game - I got it as part of a much larger bundle.Fortunately, not all is lost. The Black Mesa: Source mod (which I've played) has done what Valve failed to do - remake the campaign with proper HD graphics. Either play that game, or stick to the original 1998 game. Don't waste money buying Half-Life: Source standalone.

Posted: September 29, 2015
												Great game, way ahead of it's time and it still holds up today perhaps not graphically but definitely is strong gameplay wise and that is what's most important in a video game. It's a rollercoaster of gameplay where it constantly switches between run & gun shoot 'em up, survival horror, and puzzle platformer. It starts of strong with and immersive experience and the best intro for a video game in my personal opinion. But I have to note that the last missions in Xen are the weakest missions in the game and a painfuly difficult boss fight with an ending not worth the struggle at the end, the ending leaves you asking more question than you did at the begining of the game but the Half-Life series is known for that. But overall it's a great game and a must own, it's just the Xen missions and ending that are slightly dissapointing. I would give it an 8.5/10

Posted: May 27, 2015
												im shocked frankly!How did they ♥♥♥♥ up a game i played so much as a teen!back in the day when i was just a weeee little 13 year old, i used to pirate half life, after a while my grandparents bought me half life source and death match source, and i liked it, i got this game right around the time freeman's mind was coming out, the game was good i liked it, it was stable looked nice, and ran decently on my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ hp pavilion slimline running vista, then my account got hacked and i lost the game, now year's later im 21 and decided to buy this game again to relive some old memories, i shouldn't have, this game has some how along the line gotten worse, what was once a decently put together game ported to the source engine is broken, so here are some good and bad additions, THEY FINALLY ADDED THE HD PACK! bad news, they added the HD pack. took them long enough but its worse than anything, textures look strange and inconsistent, the hev suite has wear on it, and so do all the armor on the barneys. Sounds are missing from various weapons when you turn it on, They never fixed the crow bar making one sound on every surface, (who knew it sounded like hitting a pipe on metal when you smack soft sand) There’s this strange inconsistent shiny texture i cant turn off, looking at freeman’s mind i dont see that, and i dont remember it, its annoying and only on specific parts of the gun, Ive made it as far as residue processing and ive just stoped. the strange shinny texture glitches here and splinter’s off, almost like how raggdols would noodle in fall out or world at war, they just shoot off and splinter across the map, and this covers the entire screen, The AI in areas is broken, head crabs wont lunge at you when you stand right in front of them, good thing for those who play on hard mode like me! Posted: September 30, 2015
The black sheep of the Half-Life seriesFirst of all, Half-Life is a great game. Everyone knows that. I don't need to bother describing Half-Life's gameplay in any detail. Long story short, I loved the game then and I still do. Its influence on the industry is virtually unparalleled and indirectly led to the creation of Steam in the first place!However, Half-Life: Source is a disappointment with a misleading title. I say "misleading" because having already played Counter-Strike: Source and Day of Defeat: Source, I expected this game to be a full HD remake of the original, with proper models and textures. Instead, all we got was the original 1998 models and textures running on the Source engine. We didn't even get the polygonal upgrades that Half-Life Blue Shift received. Sure, the physics and lighting are modern, but it's hard to notice when everything else is blocky and jagged. It makes this game seem pointless especially when the original 1998 game is still available and has a much larger community. It's such a shame - I'm sure this game would've made a killing selling at full price if it were a proper HD remake. At least I didn't directly pay for this game - I got it as part of a much larger bundle.Fortunately, not all is lost. The Black Mesa: Source mod (which I've played) has done what Valve failed to do - remake the campaign with proper HD graphics. Either play that game, or stick to the original 1998 game. Don't waste money buying Half-Life: Source standalone.

												Half-Life: Source is practically no different than the original 1998 Half-Life. Ultimately, the difference comes down to more polygons, somewhat smoother animations, slightly better physics (enemies just ragdoll on death here, no predetermined animation) and shiny things. Water is also better, but the nature of this game is that it's still apparent that the game is old. However it holds up to the old standard, and the price tag is much better since you also get the Deathmatch Source game with it.

Posted: April 2, 2015
												There are legions of fans all over the Internet praising this game left and right for its innovative approach to telling a story in an FPS setting. I'll concede that point, but I'll also say that an FPS is mostly about gameplay and immersion, not about story. The gameplay in this game is pretty atrocious, because a lot of it involves jumping puzzles.Jumping puzzles, with rare exception, DO NOT WORK in an FPS. They don't. They. DON'T. If you make a jump in real life, you have a bunch of senses other than sight helping you land where you want to land. In an FPS, you've got limited sight and none of the other senses. Now I was going to give this game a pass, since it came out early on and maybe the developers simply didn't get this as they were breaking new ground in the FPS genre. But then I read that the sequel also has jumping puzzles, so they clearly didn't learn their lesson.A second flaw is the "realism" of the game. You fight a branch of the military at several points and they'll set up ambushes or minefields in which you don't see either of them coming. You need to navigate a minefield completely blind, which is realistic, but let's consider the fact that a theoretical physicist with little to no combat training fighting hordes of aliens and the military, in reality, is going to get his bullet-ridden♥♥♥♥♥handed to him in approximately 12 seconds. You pretty much need to abuse save/load to get through this game, which isn't fun at all.And what the flaming hell was up with losing all your equipment halfway through the game? That served exactly no purpose at all except to♥♥♥♥♥♥the player off. Really? The soldiers set up an ambush, like all the other ambushes Freeman had no trouble getting through, but this time they turned off the lights! Gasp! So much for realism and storytelling.Yeah, I'm not playing the sequel or the sequel to the sequel.

Posted: April 10, 2015
												If you have not yet played any version of the first Half-Life, I strongly reccommend you play the very first and original version of it, not the Source version.If you think it's a complete remake and overhaul of the original ala Counter-Strike: Source, then you would be wrong. It's just the original game ported to the Source Engine. The result is alright for a few things, but in all honesty I've found it to be less enjoyable than the original.On the plus side, the best thing I can say about is that the water looks better. Yeah, it's not much, but you can actually see through it here unlike the original, which can be helpful for getting an idea of underwater areas before diving into them and can allow you to more easily target underwater enemies without actually having to be in the water and risk attacks from them.There's also the addition of ragdolls, which generally look much nicer than the set death animations and poses NPCs took on in the original whenever they were killed.However, some enemies don't have the same behavior as in the original, some enemies are less aggressive and will not seem to notice you as often,  It might make the combat a bit easier, but that's what takes away from the gameplay, it's not quite as challenging as the original is.Other NPCs don't seem to have translated very well over to the port. One of the best examples being the friendly NPCs, Scientists and Security Guards will constantly make pain noises and grunts after being injured just once, something that's rather annoying to listen to if you want any to accompany you for backup.Overall, the game just doesn't have the same old feel of the original that I found myself enjoying and is also less challenging than it. I definitely don't recommend playing it before the original Half-Life, at the very least. It's not necessarily a "bad" remake, just one that doesn't offer enough to be favorable to the original, I feel.

Posted: April 3, 2015
												Ah Half life, possible one of my favorite game and game series of all time. I decided to pick up the old half life and try playing through it again on hard mode and it was quite a challenge for me, but a fun one nonetheless. If you have not played this game yet and are considering buying it, ask yourself this: Do i like shooters? Do i lke survival horror shooters? Do i enjoy a game with fast paced action, linear movement of story, easter eggs, fun, and a game that is just so good that i cant possibly resist playing it? If you answered yes to any of those questions then this game is right for you. A word of advice though, this is the source version so while osme textures are improved there are an abundance of bugs, glitches, and new errors. if your willing to look past all that (which is easy to do) then buy this version. If not then just buy the original half life. Either way I highly recommend this game as it is easily a lifetime classic.

Posted: July 13, 2014
												A very good and original game, I can see how this game could've been so influential back in 1998 because of all the tiny details that you didn't get in a FPS game then, things such as interacting with your environment by means of pushing boxes and knocking out vent openings and leading guards and scientists to open doors for you, to name a couple of them. The game keeps you entertained throughout its duration and doesn't get boring once, you're either gunning your way through an area full of enemies or solving a puzzle to get through a different area and testing your resourcefulness and intelligence; the horror aspect is eerie and creepy without resorting to many jumpscares that today's "horror" games do so much of.The game hasn't gotten old either, you can still play this game today nearly 20 years since its release and it will still deliver as enjoyable if you don't mind the old fashioned graphics and audio, of course!

												If you want to play HL in the source engine, than this is THE version for you! They don't realy change to much of the game. But some graphical things are pretty much improved. You're now able to add motion blur and other new graphical stuff that makes the game look a lot better. They also keep the tone and mood from the first game by including all of the original textures. But some of the sounds (Like the foodsteps) are directly from HL2 witch makes the game sound alot better. Posted: December 28, 2013
												Half-Life: a fantastic game, and a keystone in the development of the modern first-person shooter. If you're into nostalgic titles - even if you have no experience in the Half-Life franchise - then this game is for you. I'm amazed at how well the gameplay holds up today. Obviously, its age shows, but that doesn't hinder its sense of fun. Because that's what this game is - fun. Extremely, unbearably, unrelentingly fun. It doesn't take itself too seriously, but it’s gritty enough to avoid that stupid tongue-in-cheek pretentiousness that a lot of late 90's shooters have. I've never played a game that matches the level of ridiculousness this has without upsetting the suspension of disbelief. When you step into the pixelated (and non-existent) shoes of one Gordon Freeman, you honestly won't bat an eyelid at the fact that you're suddenly smashing in a one-eyed alien dog’s face with a crowbar. It won't click that the scientists all look like a♥♥♥♥♥♥drawing of Albert Einstein, or a polygonal potato motion captured by a person without joints in their limbs. You won't notice that the voice acting sounds like it was filled in by whoever was hanging around the office that evening. When you just play it, all of the game's wrinkles quickly iron out. And do you know why?  Because you'll enjoy the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of it.  The awesome level design, the kickass weapons, the seamless integration of puzzles and gunplay – they all come together to create this milestone in gaming history. The game that gave us Valve, the game that forged the modern FPS, the game that brought modding communities to the frontline - this game is all of those, and so much more.All of that being said, the game's transfer to the source engine feels a little... pointless. Having played through both versions, the only substantial differences I've seen are the improved water textures - which are rendered with the source engine’s better shaders, (looking incongruous given the more aged textures of the remainder of the game) some slightly improved lighting effects and the source's superior physics engine -  which this version does a fantastic job of ignoring. While Half-Life is a classic title, this new version adds essentially nothing in terms of gameplay, and yet it is several gigabytes larger in installation size. Frankly, if I could choose between the two again, I would choose the original version. There’s a strange appeal in playing such a definitive title in the original, intended, unaltered form. Of course, the original game has its own set of flaws – the increasingly infuriating Xen segment being one of them – however, when we’re dealing with a title as significant as this, those flaws all become water under the bridge. This is a marginally improved version of a fantastic game with an indomitable sense of fun - I'd recommend this game to anyone who's looking for a good romp at the fast-paced FPS's of olden times.

Posted: April 17, 2011
												This game played a key role in the transition to full 3D in first person gaming. After the richness and depth seen at the climax of the '2.5D' era, the move to full 3D seemed to throw all that advancement out the window. Whereas the 2.5D era had reached a point where such depth was near inherent, successors like Quake and Quake 2 showed a simplicity that while enjoyable, left an undeniable lacking. And gone were so many of the innovations defined by the previous era. On consoles, a game named Golden Eye brought many of those past innovations kicking and screaming, into the 3D space; On PC, at the forefront of the charge, rode the mighty Half Life. Granted, despite the game's release, the war remained unwon, but the battle was a major victory, and Half Life will never be forgotten.

												Half Life is (of course) a fantastic game. This is a good version of it.Pros:-Improved water, bullet, lighting, and physics effects-Ragdolls are cool-Fixed some annoying issues from the original-Levels can be accessed individually, and you're given a sizeable arsenal to startNeutral:-Same graphics in generalCons:-Occasionally a scripted event won't execute properly, such as a door not opening on "Surface Tension" or being teleported to a glitchy place on "Lamba Core". Luckily these were at the very end of their respective levels, so I just skipped ahead to the next one. These are a pain in the butt. However, I've also heard this was an issue with the original.-Some sound effects don't work when you choose the option to "Load HD models". This is annoying because the HD models look way better.Overall, if you've played the original recently, there isn't much new or different here. I would recomend it for new players looking to play a classic game.

Posted: February 1, 2015
												As big a visual improvement Half-Life Source is over the original, it's sadly riddled with bugs. On first play, I wasn't able to progress past the first chapter as the game script appeared to be broken when a security guard or scientist was supposed to open a door for me but wouldn't. There are also numerous sound and rendering issues, such as weapons being invisible and the sound of your gund being played in the distance. There's a particularly nasty bug on one of the levels where a storm drain is blocked by a grate that isn't meant to be there. The only way past was to use the noclip cheat.With the original Half-Life on Steam for the same price, the graphics won't be as good but you won't get these game-destroying bugs. Avoid.

												This game is almost exactly the same as the original Half-Life, the only difference is that it runs on a different engine (some levels are slightly different).The original Half-Life is a much better choice to buy, because it has a wide choice of mods to play once you have completed the main game. I don't believe I have ever found any mods for this game.Only buy this game if you want the same game as the original, but on a different engine.A better choice is to buy the Source mod, Black mesa. Black mesa is basically a remake of Half-Life, it is basically what the modders believed Half-Life Source should have been.For a review on the actual game, please see my Half-Life review.

Posted: November 26, 2014
												Yeah, wow. When I finally got this years after release due to new PC that could handle games, I played only using quicksave until I jumped to the wrong place and could not get back! It was hard, because it was the wrong way!Anyway, I have faint memories from several areas of the game, but never a continious run. Right now I'm playing through it in the DK2 to get the complete package. The Source version does polish up the original quite a bit, there are many HD models, water effects, shadows, modelled environments instead of cube-maps etc. I paid for this separately, and I'm happy I did.As for playing in VR, of course it's awesome, but. Before doing this I've played 30h+ of HL2 in the DK1, 15h+ of the episodes in DK2, as well as a ton of other VR experiences. This game, HL1, is not for the person without VR legs if you want to play it with supreme immersion. You run super fast, close to the ground, haha. At first it was a bit crazy, but now nine hours later I'm very used to it, and I plan on finishing the entire thing in the DK2.A classic I never experienced at the time, but I still remember seeing it when visiting a friend. I only had time to sit through the intro, the loader robot still amazed me, and the character models... THEY MOVE THEIR MOUTHS. And chromed helmets on the guards... amazing stuff guys.

												Which is better, Half-Life or the Source version? Well, that depends on what your willing to deal with between the two. Half-Life Source looks quite a bit better than the origanal with its water effects, motion blur, and fixed box-pushing machanic. However, unlike the origanal, Source DOES NOT have an auto save! So you could progress throu the entire game, die right at the end, and start over at that damn long tram ride. Another thing to mention is the enimies just love to get right in your face, so be perpared to use you shotgun alot. As long as your willing to deal with that, and have a habit of pressing the F6 key, then go ahead and get Half-Life Source. Otherwise, just stick with regular Half-Life.*Note: In case anyone hasn't played a Valve game before, F6 is the manuel save.*****

Posted: January 17, 2015
												If you've played the original 1998 Half-Life game then playing through Half-Life: Source will essentially mean playing through the same game for at least a second time. The classic base game is the same and nothing from the original has been left out. Half-Life: Source just makes use of Valve's newer proprietary Source engine since the original Half-Life was built on and ran on the Goldsrc engine.There are some noticeable differences in the game being ported over to use the Source engine and most of the improvements are to the graphics, textures and effects. Most areas do not have a significant and obvious amount of refurbishing but I observed the following areas of improvement.Firstly, the weapons appear more slick such as a more smooth edged and shiny crowbar which is a nice touch but nothing radical. The next graphical improvements that are noticeable would be things like the water effects which make the water ripples and flow look and feel a lot more realistic. The overall texture of everything in the game has been slightly or greatly improved on. Since the game is using the Source engine you will find the title menu has been changed to reflect the new engine which feels like Half-Life 2's main title menu.The whole point of this version of Half-Life is to showcase the original classic in its glorious transition from the original Goldsrc engine to the newer Source engine. This is the reason why the original Half-Life's multiplayer component is left out because if you want to play the multiplayer aspect of the game then the original is what it's intended for.One area of Half-Life: Source which appears to mildly hinder the experience are the loading screens. There are frequent, and sometimes considerably long loading screens. The original Half-Life had some loading screens which were very short but Half-Life: Source seems to have them at regular intervals and with quite a delay. I'm guessing this issue is mainly to do with the new engine adopted for the game. However, if you can put up with this then the game is still brilliant and this will not really be anything of significant concern.I've noticed quite a few negative comments for this version of Half-Life and they state that things in the game are broken such as helicopter hit boxes. This is actually incorrect because I haven't had any difficulties with taking down helicopters in the Dam level and other levels. You just need to be aware of the right tactics.Overall, the game is essentially the same as the original with a nice polish and I have also reviewed the original Half-Life on Steam so checking that review out will provide complementary views on this game as well. If you've played Half-Life (original) on Steam or elsewhere then playing Half-Life: Source isn't really necessary. The only reason you would play it is out of curiosity like me and because it is a fairly short game. An excellent classic nonetheless.

Posted: February 1, 2015
												As big a visual improvement Half-Life Source is over the original, it's sadly riddled with bugs. On first play, I wasn't able to progress past the first chapter as the game script appeared to be broken when a security guard or scientist was supposed to open a door for me but wouldn't. There are also numerous sound and rendering issues, such as weapons being invisible and the sound of your gund being played in the distance. There's a particularly nasty bug on one of the levels where a storm drain is blocked by a grate that isn't meant to be there. The only way past was to use the noclip cheat.With the original Half-Life on Steam for the same price, the graphics won't be as good but you won't get these game-destroying bugs. Avoid.

Posted: January 28, 2015
												Half Life is (of course) a fantastic game. This is a good version of it.Pros:-Improved water, bullet, lighting, and physics effects-Ragdolls are cool-Fixed some annoying issues from the original-Levels can be accessed individually, and you're given a sizeable arsenal to startNeutral:-Same graphics in generalCons:-Occasionally a scripted event won't execute properly, such as a door not opening on "Surface Tension" or being teleported to a glitchy place on "Lamba Core". Luckily these were at the very end of their respective levels, so I just skipped ahead to the next one. These are a pain in the butt. However, I've also heard this was an issue with the original.-Some sound effects don't work when you choose the option to "Load HD models". This is annoying because the HD models look way better.Overall, if you've played the original recently, there isn't much new or different here. I would recomend it for new players looking to play a classic game.

Posted: February 26, 2016
												Graphics and Bugs:This game is an original Half-Life but on the source engine. Which means better graphics and less bugs and glitches. On the original Half-Life the sound could not be heard sometimes, here its fixed. But really rare there is a ladder bug when you jump on ladder and it knocks you off (requires restart) and basically thats it.Difficulty and genre:Luckily the game was developed a long ago, when the story was not very important, when developers were adding much more action than in modern games. Yeah of cource it has story, and events but nothing complicated. The athmosphere and action are something to enjoy in this game. It is difficult even on easy difficulty to find where to go, or just complete the chapters (some take 1-2 hours). But I would call it ''challenging'' instead of ''omg sucks'' or ''too hard''The start and end of game:The start was clear, whole chapter spent on introduction which is kind of needed to be done. The end had some kind of mystery, and some questions could be asked. Has two endings, and you can only hope what Gordon is going to choose.Rating:I would give this game 9/10. First played in 2015, and it is a game for all the times!

Posted: September 29, 2015
												Great game, way ahead of it's time and it still holds up today perhaps not graphically but definitely is strong gameplay wise and that is what's most important in a video game. It's a rollercoaster of gameplay where it constantly switches between run & gun shoot 'em up, survival horror, and puzzle platformer. It starts of strong with and immersive experience and the best intro for a video game in my personal opinion. But I have to note that the last missions in Xen are the weakest missions in the game and a painfuly difficult boss fight with an ending not worth the struggle at the end, the ending leaves you asking more question than you did at the begining of the game but the Half-Life series is known for that. But overall it's a great game and a must own, it's just the Xen missions and ending that are slightly dissapointing. I would give it an 8.5/10

Posted: September 30, 2015
The black sheep of the Half-Life seriesFirst of all, Half-Life is a great game. Everyone knows that. I don't need to bother describing Half-Life's gameplay in any detail. Long story short, I loved the game then and I still do. Its influence on the industry is virtually unparalleled and indirectly led to the creation of Steam in the first place!However, Half-Life: Source is a disappointment with a misleading title. I say "misleading" because having already played Counter-Strike: Source and Day of Defeat: Source, I expected this game to be a full HD remake of the original, with proper models and textures. Instead, all we got was the original 1998 models and textures running on the Source engine. We didn't even get the polygonal upgrades that Half-Life Blue Shift received. Sure, the physics and lighting are modern, but it's hard to notice when everything else is blocky and jagged. It makes this game seem pointless especially when the original 1998 game is still available and has a much larger community. It's such a shame - I'm sure this game would've made a killing selling at full price if it were a proper HD remake. At least I didn't directly pay for this game - I got it as part of a much larger bundle.Fortunately, not all is lost. The Black Mesa: Source mod (which I've played) has done what Valve failed to do - remake the campaign with proper HD graphics. Either play that game, or stick to the original 1998 game. Don't waste money buying Half-Life: Source standalone.

Posted: February 1, 2015
												As big a visual improvement Half-Life Source is over the original, it's sadly riddled with bugs. On first play, I wasn't able to progress past the first chapter as the game script appeared to be broken when a security guard or scientist was supposed to open a door for me but wouldn't. There are also numerous sound and rendering issues, such as weapons being invisible and the sound of your gund being played in the distance. There's a particularly nasty bug on one of the levels where a storm drain is blocked by a grate that isn't meant to be there. The only way past was to use the noclip cheat.With the original Half-Life on Steam for the same price, the graphics won't be as good but you won't get these game-destroying bugs. Avoid.

Posted: January 28, 2015
												Half Life is (of course) a fantastic game. This is a good version of it.Pros:-Improved water, bullet, lighting, and physics effects-Ragdolls are cool-Fixed some annoying issues from the original-Levels can be accessed individually, and you're given a sizeable arsenal to startNeutral:-Same graphics in generalCons:-Occasionally a scripted event won't execute properly, such as a door not opening on "Surface Tension" or being teleported to a glitchy place on "Lamba Core". Luckily these were at the very end of their respective levels, so I just skipped ahead to the next one. These are a pain in the butt. However, I've also heard this was an issue with the original.-Some sound effects don't work when you choose the option to "Load HD models". This is annoying because the HD models look way better.Overall, if you've played the original recently, there isn't much new or different here. I would recomend it for new players looking to play a classic game.

Posted: March 11, 2015
												For me, after 19 years, Half-Life is still very playable, nowadays, often underrestimate game, with sadly not astonishing storyline and thrilling gameplay. The game's climate of secret insitution (based on 'Area 64' idea) and underground labs is perfect. I won't be saying anything about graphics since at 1998 it was delightful, however the sound quality could be definitely way better. Storytelling technique was highly sophisticated since it was told more visually than in text. The game guarantees tons of action and fun. Personaly - as my favourite one - I find it the best in the series and now, Source engine is making it even better. Thank you Valve. Quick summary: +perfect climate of secret institution and labs situated underground +very good graphics (to the standards of '98) +good storytelling technique +dynamic, full of action gameplay based on shooting creatures +Valve's Source engine is making it even better -sound quality -despite that it got old quite good, it is still the game from previous generation -not astonishing storyScore: 7/10

Half-Life (Source)Positives• Most likely a good game in 1998• Simplistic shooting mechanics that make sense• Ammo and resources have to be found and are sometimes scarceNegatives• Repetitive and senseless puzzles• Enemies are too easy to take out and are just a nuisance rather than a challenge• Gordon seems to be too powerful for a protagonist fighting mutants and hundreds of soldiers• Graphics are never updated and is a bit bad for my liking even though it is an older title• Story is a bit dragged out mostly due to the annoying puzzles which make the game seem choppy• Player physics are very buggy in the source version, for example you can run way too fast• Seems like nothing changed between Source and original• Outdated and stale for todays standards• Frustrating, boring and repetitive at times• Pointless shooting and slaughtering predictable enemiesFinal Thoughts: Although the game came out more than ten years ago, it still does not make up for the boring and repetitive gameplay. I got this game because I wanted the whole Half-Life story but the story was ruined in this version. I could barely get through the first 5 hours when all Gordon was doing was escaping the facility.Rating: 2.5/10-Penta

Posted: January 24, 2016
												The bad reviews are overexaggerating the glitches in this. For a large majority of the time, this is just Half Life with some better textures and skyboxes. I only found one bug that was game-breaking, and that was the whole entire area going absolutely crazy in one level. Textures were bending and it all looked like an orgy of gray and white tentacles that you'd usually find in those poorly made Garry's Mod lobbies. Besides that, the game runs fine, and I could skip the level anyways because you can choose to start at any level you want even when you first play, instead of unlocking them like you would in the original Half Life.It gets rid of some of the minor faults from Half Life and replaces them with equally minor faults. It's still Half Life.

Posted: January 1
												So this is the first time I have ever played a Half-Life game, and in my first 2 hours of playing, I can say that this game is fantastic. It does not have 10 to 20 minute cutscenes with loads of dialogue, nor is it a team multiplayer that you respawn in several times per round, but it is the beginning of the fps with a plot and the chaotic environment of Portal 2, which coincidentally both use valve's Source engine, albeit rougher image quality in Half-Life because it has been ported to this engine while it was in its early days. It does become a little addicting once you start playing because you start at ground zero and have to work your way out of hell the facility to escape while others around you are much less fortunate. It isn't the prettiest game out there, nor is it one with a story so intricate that writing it down would result in a book larger than the Harry Potter series, but it is gripping enough that just by playing the first game, (and Half-Life can never be mention without mentioning Half-Life 3) I can understand why fans want a Half-Life 3. Plus the whole series is available for less than $10 during sales (I got mine during the Winter 2016 sale).

Posted: July 22, 2012
												I remember seeing this in a game magazine when the internet was still a shaddy thing, the graphics were amazing and it was yet to be released, it was expected to be one of the best and most promising game releases of 1998. I still remember how 'stupid' the name felt to me at the time, little did I know the weight this franchise would carry in the next 14 years.I first touched this game at a friends house, it was amazingly brilliant, it looked like a movie, it WAS a movie, something that had never been done, a game with a movie-category introduction, it was something groundbreaking in game history.This is a must-play-before-you-die for any hardcore gamer.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												One of the best FPSs of all time. At some point in your life you must have heard about this game, or it sequel. Every game in the genre borrows some elements from this one, guaranteed. The arms you with a handful of weapons you mst make your way though a ridiculously big research facility overrun with aliens and military forces. A non stop action package with zero cutscenes.The story is explained through small chats with the surviving members of the facility and paying attention to enemy  conversations. You can also gather some extra details by cautiously examining the environment.All the enemy soldiers have an instantly recognizeable scruffy voice while the friendly NPCs sound more calmed and soft, for the most part. This game also has some os the most well known scores for PC games (like the Nuclear Mission jam), and the weapon sounds are very well made.Although this is a remake of the original release for the source engine the graphics were not enhanced at all, so don't expect brilliant quality. Some users also say this version is inferior to the original because it added extra bugs and other issues, but I encountered none during my playthrough. Your mileage may vary though.Overall, this game is a classic and a must play for anyone who enjoys videogames.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												Half life is an important game in the history of gaming, the main reason Half LIfe is so ground breaking is the amazing story. The game follows a story line that's somewhat complicated, but very interesting. You play as the character Dr. Gordon Freeman who works as a theoretical physics at the Black Mesa Research Facility. Posted: March 13, 2016
												Half Life really put other games I've played into perspective. I've always had my hand held, always had a little floating marker telling me, "Go here, push this, kill that." I've always been showered in health, just so I don't go crying to mommy because I was't taking cover. But not in half life. The puzzles are tough and not thoroughly explained, so I found myslef checking the walkthrough often (FYI, I am stupid). I still found it fun, and the platforming wan't overly impossible. What I liked most about HL was the combat. In CoD or some other modern shooter, you crouch behind a wall for 5 seconds and your bullet holes magicaly heal themselves. In Half Life, you can get knocked down to 2 health with no medkits nearby. It is then that the stakes are raised higher than any spunk-gargle weewee shooter(From Zero Punctuation). You have to fight your way to a medkit while avoiding any kind of damage, since a tiny papercut to your pinky will kill you. Then when you finaly get said medkit, it gives a sense of accomplishment that you can never get from gunning down countless foriengers from behind a brown chest-high wall.Overall, a very fun game and a good representation of how games have changed.

Posted: January 18, 2016
Half-Life (Source)Positives• Most likely a good game in 1998• Simplistic shooting mechanics that make sense• Ammo and resources have to be found and are sometimes scarceNegatives• Repetitive and senseless puzzles• Enemies are too easy to take out and are just a nuisance rather than a challenge• Gordon seems to be too powerful for a protagonist fighting mutants and hundreds of soldiers• Graphics are never updated and is a bit bad for my liking even though it is an older title• Story is a bit dragged out mostly due to the annoying puzzles which make the game seem choppy• Player physics are very buggy in the source version, for example you can run way too fast• Seems like nothing changed between Source and original• Outdated and stale for todays standards• Frustrating, boring and repetitive at times• Pointless shooting and slaughtering predictable enemiesFinal Thoughts: Although the game came out more than ten years ago, it still does not make up for the boring and repetitive gameplay. I got this game because I wanted the whole Half-Life story but the story was ruined in this version. I could barely get through the first 5 hours when all Gordon was doing was escaping the facility.Rating: 2.5/10-Penta

												"Rice and shine doctor Freeman. Rice and shine" Original quote from me in 2012. Man things change do they not? I am a somewhat grown person now! Anyway HL1 Is one of the best games i played after completing HL2. As i wanted the full experience but i also wanted a more "fun" version. Answer? HL:S Was the answer! Posted: December 27, 2016
												This game is a fps classic from the 90s. Its a great game and its one of those games where you need to use your brain. Games today are waaay to easy in my opinion and mostly just tell you what and how to keep progressing kinda like the game is playing you other than you playing it. This game however has zero cut scenes and really no help on how to complete an objective which i really like. Also shows how a game can be great without all the fancy graphics and cut scenes. You play as a scientist named freeman and you need to progress through the Black Masa complex after something goes completely wrong. Has a great pace of movement speed and enemies who are very accurate when they shoot you. The Ai/NPC's are not all that stupid. They know how to duck to cover and rush and kill you with out just standing still so you have a clear shot on them. Marines you fight can be brutal at times especially when you are out numbered and out gunned. Even in today of 2016 I enjoyed this classic very much and actualy preffer this type of game over plenty of new ones of today. Just because a game looks good doesnt mean its going to be good. I always wondered why this game was a legend and now I understand. Ill tell you this there will be moments when you will get stuck and this game isnt that easy. If you havent played Half-Life I really recommend that you do. You will see how much back pacing games of today have made compared to some games like this from the 90s. Great music tracks great gameplay and great story all wraped into one. You should buy this game.

Posted: January 1
												So this is the first time I have ever played a Half-Life game, and in my first 2 hours of playing, I can say that this game is fantastic. It does not have 10 to 20 minute cutscenes with loads of dialogue, nor is it a team multiplayer that you respawn in several times per round, but it is the beginning of the fps with a plot and the chaotic environment of Portal 2, which coincidentally both use valve's Source engine, albeit rougher image quality in Half-Life because it has been ported to this engine while it was in its early days. It does become a little addicting once you start playing because you start at ground zero and have to work your way out of hell the facility to escape while others around you are much less fortunate. It isn't the prettiest game out there, nor is it one with a story so intricate that writing it down would result in a book larger than the Harry Potter series, but it is gripping enough that just by playing the first game, (and Half-Life can never be mention without mentioning Half-Life 3) I can understand why fans want a Half-Life 3. Plus the whole series is available for less than $10 during sales (I got mine during the Winter 2016 sale).
